target: In addition to a radio edit of the original song, the single release contains a remix by Canadian electronica artist Akufen, as well as "I Against I", a song performed with Mos Def that appeared on the soundtrack of the 2002 film "Blade II".

source: 12" vinyl releases contained an additional remix of "Special Cases" by Vladislav Delay, who is credited as "Luomo" for this release.
target: 12" vinyl releases contained more remixes of "Special Cases" by Vladislav Delay, who is credited as "Luomo" for this release.

source: Two separate music videos were made for the song.
target: The song was also made into two separate videos.

source: The Enhanced CD contains one of these, and the other video is on a rare DVD release of the single.
target: The Enhanced CD contains one of these, and the other video is on a rare DVD release of the single.

source: Exeter St David's is the principal railway station serving the city of Exeter in Devon, England.
target: Exeter St Davids railway station is the main train station in Exeter, England.

source: The station was opened on 1 May 1844 by the Bristol and Exeter Railway (B&ER).
target: The station opened on 1 May 1844.

source: Exeter St David's is the second busiest station in Devon, handling around 2,605,166 passengers a year in 2016/17.
target: It is the second busiest station in Devon, with around 200,000 fewer customers each year than Plymouth.

source: Comparing the year from April 2007 to that which started in April 2002, passenger numbers increased by 30%.
target: Passenger numbers increased by 30% between April 2002 and April 2007..

source: There are two direct routes from St David's to London.
target: There are two ways from St Davids to London.

source: The main line is generally considered to be the Great Western Railway service via the Reading–Taunton line to London Paddington but there is also a service operated by South Western Railway on their West of England Main Line to London Waterloo via Salisbury and Basingstoke.
target: The main line is the First Great Western service by the Bristol to Exeter line to Paddington station, but there is also a trains by South West Trains on the West of England Main Line to Waterloo.

source: Because of this the station is one of the few that have trains to London departing in opposite directions at either end of the station – those to Paddington leave northwards while those to Waterloo head south but turn eastwards, and start the steep climb to Exeter Central just outside the station.
target: The station is one of the few that have trains to London going in other ways at both ends of the station.

source: Further long-distance services are operated by CrossCountry to Birmingham New Street, Manchester Piccadilly , Sheffield, Leeds, York, , Edinburgh, Glasgow and Aberdeen.
target: There are also trains by CrossCountry to Birmingham New Street, the North of England and Scotland.

source: Musicians often have a musical repertoire.
target: Most famous musicians have a wide repertoire (they can play a lot of pieces).

source: A banyan, also spelled "banian", is a fig that begins its life as an epiphyte, i.e. a plant that grows on another plant, when its seed germinates in a crack or crevice of a host tree or edifice. However, many seeds fall on the branches and stems of other trees or on human edifices, and when they germinate they grow roots down toward the ground and consequently may envelop part of the host tree or edifice.
target: A banyan (or 'banian') is a kind of fig. It usually starts life by growing on another plant as an epiphyte. Its seeds germinate in the cracks and crevices on a host tree, or on other structures like buildings and bridges. The seeds germinate and send down roots towards the ground.

source: "Banyan" often specifically denominates "Ficus benghalensis" (the "Indian banyan"), which is the national tree of the Republic of India, though the name has also been generalized to denominate all figs that share a common life cycle and used systematically in taxonomy to denominate the subgenus Urostigma.
target: "Banyan" usually means the Indian banyan or "Ficus benghalensis".

source: For this reason banyans bear the colloquial name "strangler fig". A number of tropical banyan species that compete for sunlight, especially of the genus "Ficus", exhibit this strangling habit.
target: A number of tropical forest species grow by strangling. Any "Ficus" species showing this habit may be termed a strangler fig.

source: The leaves of the banyan tree are large, leathery, glossy, green, and elliptical.
target: The leaves of the banyan tree are large, leathery, glossy green and elliptical in shape.

source: Like most figs, the leaf bud is covered by two large scales.
target: Like most of the fig-trees, the leaf bud is covered by two large scales.

source: As the leaf develops the scales abscise.
target: As the leaf develops the scales fall.

source: Young leaves have an attractive reddish tinge.
target: Young leaves have an attractive reddish tinge.

source: Older banyan trees are characterized by aerial prop roots that mature into thick, woody trunks, which can become indistinguishable from the primary trunk with age.
target: Older banyan trees have aerial prop roots that grow into thick woody trunks which, with age, can become indistinguishable from the main trunk.

source: Old trees can spread laterally by using these prop roots to grow over a wide area.
target: Old trees can spread out laterally using these prop roots to cover a wide area.

source: Over time, the name became generalized to all strangler figs of the "Urostigma" subgenus.
target: They are put in the subgenus Urostigma.

source: Ardres is a commune in the Pas-de-Calais department in northern France.
target: Ardres is a commune.

source: Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi (Sinhala: ජය ශ්‍රී මහා බොධිය) is a sacred fig tree in the Mahamewna Gardens, Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka.
target: The Sri Maha Bodhi is a Sacred Fig tree in Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka.

source: It is said to be the southern branch from the historical Sri Maha Bodhi at Buddha Gaya in India under which Lord Buddha attained Enlightenment.
target: It is said to be a tree grown from a sapling from the famous Bodhi tree under which the first Buddha became enlightened, which was brought down by Mihindu (Mahinda) and Sangamittha Maha Thero. The tree is said to be the southern branch of the Jaya Siri Maha Bodhi at Bodh Gaya in India under which the first Buddha attained Enlightenment.

source: It was planted in 288 BC, and is the oldest living human-planted tree in the world with a known planting date.
target: It was planted in 288 BC, and is the oldest living human-planted tree in the world with a known planting date.

source: In the 3rd century BC, it was brought to Sri Lanka by Sangamitta Theri (Pali; Skt.: Sanghamitra), the daughter of Emperor Asoka and founder of an order of Buddhist nuns in Sri Lanka.
target: In the 3rd century BC, the Buddha's fig tree was brought to Sri Lanka by the Their Sangamitta, daughter of Emperor Asoka and founder of an order of Buddhist nuns, in Sri Lanka.

source: The present wall was constructed by "Ilupandeniye Athtadassi" Thero during the reign of King Kirti Sri Rajasinha (r. 1747-1782), to protect it from wild elephants which might have damaged the tree.
target: This wall was built during the reign of King Kirthi Sri Rajasingha, to protect it from wild elephants which might have attacked the tree.

source: Beary or Byari (ಬ್ಯಾರಿ ಬಾಸೆ "Byāri Bāse") is an Indian language spoken by the Muslim communities mainly of Karnataka (Dakshina Kannada and Udupi districts) and some parts of North Kerala ("Byaris").
target: Beary language is an Indian language. It is spoken by the Muslim communities of Karnataka (Dakshina Kannada and Udupi districts) and some parts of Kerala.

source: Bearys speak a language made of Malayalam idioms with Tulu phonology and grammar.
target: Bearys speak a language made of Malayalam idioms (form of expression of a language) with Tulu pronunciation and grammar.

source: The first Beary-language feature film "Byari" shared the award for the best feature film at the 59th Indian National Film Awards.
target: The first Beary language feature movie (full length movie) "Byari" shared the award for the best feature movie at the 59th Indian National Film Awards.

source: Whitstable is a seaside town on the north coast of Kent in south-east England, 5 miles (8 km) north of Canterbury and 2 miles (3 km) west of Herne Bay.
target: Whiststable is a small seaside town in Kent, southeast England.

source: Whitstable was famous for its 'Native Oysters' which were collected from beds beyond the low water mark from Roman times until the mid-20th century.
target: The town is famous for its oysters which have been collected there since the Roman period.

source: Whitstable, along with Herne Bay and Canterbury, is in the City of Canterbury local government district.
target: It is a few miles north of Canterbury, near Herne Bay.

source: The Chronicles of Life and Death is the third studio album by American rock band Good Charlotte, released through Epic and Daylight Records on October 5, 2004. Initially planned for release in September, "The Chronicles of Life and Death" was released on October 5 through Epic and Daylight Records.
target: The Chronicles of Life and Death is the third studio album by American pop punk band, Good Charlotte. "The Chronicles of Life and Death" was released on October 5, 2004.

source: The album was released with two different versions: a "Life" and a "Death" version which came with different cover art (designed by guitarist Billy Martin) and a special bonus track. It was released in two different editions: Life (with "Falling Away" as a bonus track) and Death (with "Meet My Maker" as a bonus track), both with different artwork created by Martin.
target: It was released with both a "Life" and a "Death" version.

source: There is also a Japanese version that has a different cover art as well as the special bonus tracks from both the "Life" and "Death" versions, including the hidden track "Wounded" at the end of the album.
target: The life version contained a bonus track called "Falling Away" which also featured the hidden track "Wounded".

source: "The Chronicles of Life and Death" is the only album to feature Chris Wilson on drums.
target: It was the first and last album to feature Chris Wilson on the drums.

source: Pontvallain is a commune in the Sarthe department in the region of Pays-de-la-Loire in north-western France.
target: Pontvallain is a commune. It is found in the region Pays de la Loire in the Sarthe department in the west of France.

source: The Tube map (sometimes called the London Underground Map or the TfL Services Map) is a schematic transport map of the lines, stations and services of the London Underground, known colloquially as "the Tube", hence the map's name. The Tube map exists to help passengers navigate the London rapid transit network and it has been questioned whether it should play a wider role in helping people navigate London itself.
target: The Tube Map, is a map that navigates passengers around London using the London Underground, London Overground, Docklands Light Railway, and Emirates Air-line. The Tube Map helps navigate over a billion journeys a year in the biggest city in Europe.

source: The Workers' Party of Korea (WPK) is the founding and ruling political party of North Korea.
target: Workers' Party of Korea is the current ruling party in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea.

source: It was founded in 1949 with the merger of the Workers' Party of North Korea and the Workers' Party of South Korea. A year later on 30 June 1949, the Workers' Party of Korea was created with the merger of the WPNK and the Workers' Party of South Korea.
target: The Workers' Party of Korea was established on June 30, 1949 by Kim Il-sung as its leader. On 30 June 1949, the Workers' Party of Korea was formed based on the merger between the Communist Party of Korea and the new Democratic Party of Korea.

source: At the 4th Party Conference on 11 April, Kim Jong-il was declared Eternal General Secretary and Kim Jong-un was elected to the newly created post of First Secretary of the Workers' Party of Korea and the Presidium.
target: The first secretary of the Communist Party of Korea was Kim Yong-bom.

source: Steven Rodney McQueen (born 9 October 1969) is a British film director and screenwriter.
target: Steven Rodney "Steve" McQueen, CBE (born 9 October 1969) is a British movie director and artist.

source: McQueen's other feature films are "Hunger" (2008), a historical drama about the 1981 Irish hunger strike, "Shame" (2011), a drama about an executive struggling with sex addiction, and "Widows" (2018), a thriller about a group of women who vow to finish the heist their husbands died attempting. His 2008 feature film "Hunger", about the 1981 Irish hunger strike, premiered at the 2008 Cannes Film Festival.
target: In 2008 "Hunger" was released.

source: For his artwork, McQueen has received the Turner Prize, the highest award given to a British visual artist. He won the Turner Prize in 1999, although much of the publicity went to Tracey Emin, who was also a nominee.
target: In 1999 McQueen won the Turner Prize.

source: McQueen was born in London and is of Grenadian and Trinidadian descent.
target: McQueen was born in London and is of Grenadian descent.

source: He grew up in Hanwell, West London and went to Drayton Manor High School.
target: He went to Drayton Manor High School.

source: He took A level art at Ealing, Hammersmith and West London College, then studied art and design at Chelsea College of Arts and then fine art at Goldsmiths College, University of London, where he first became interested in film.
target: After doing A Level art at Hammersmith and West London College he went to Goldsmiths College, University of London.

source: "Bear" (1993) was McQueen's first major film, presented at the Royal College of Art in London.
target: In 1993 his first major movie "Bear" was shown at the Royal College of Art in London.

source: As well as being in black-and-white, both these films are silent.
target: It is black and white and there is no sound in it.

source: McQueen signed on to develop "Codes of Conduct", a six-episode limited series for HBO. McQueen is working on a BBC drama about the lives of black Britons, which follows the lives of a group of friends and their families from 1968 to 2014.
target: McQueen is making a drama for HBO.

source: In addition to London, since 1997 McQueen has a home in Amsterdam, with his Dutch wife, cultural critic Bianca Stigter, and their two children.
target: McQueen lives in Amsterdam with Bianca Stigter.

source: The 2010 Winter Olympics, officially known as the XXI Olympic Winter Games and commonly known as Vancouver 2010, informally the 21st Winter Olympics, was an international winter multi-sport event that was held from 12 to 28 February 2010 in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, with some events held in the surrounding suburbs of Richmond, West Vancouver and the University Endowment Lands, and in the nearby resort town of Whistler. The 2010 Winter Olympics featured 86 events over 15 disciplines in 7 sports.
target: The 2010 Winter Olympics, officially known as the XXI Olympic Winter Games, were the Winter Olympics that were held in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada in 2010. The XXI Olympic Winter Games were held from February 14 2010 to February 28 2010. Many of the 2010 events were held in the nearby resort community called Whistler, about an hour's drive north of Vancouver. The opening and closing ceremonies and the events grouped as ice sports (excluding bobsleigh, luge and skeleton) were held in Vancouver and Richmond.

source: Both the Olympic and Paralympic Games were organized by the Vancouver Organizing Committee (VANOC), headed by John Furlong.
target: Both the Olympic and Paralympic Games were organized by the Vancouver Organizing Committee (VANOC).

source: The 2010 Winter Olympics were the third Olympics hosted by Canada and the first by the province of British Columbia.
target: The 2010 Winter Olympics is the third Olympics hosted by Canada, and the first by the province of British Columbia.

source: Canada hosted the 1976 Summer Olympics in Montreal, Quebec, and the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary, Alberta.
target: Previously, Canada was home to the 1976 Summer Olympics in Montreal and the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary.

source: Competition venues in Whistler included Whistler Creekside at the Whistler Blackcomb ski resort, the Whistler Olympic Park, the Whistler Celebration Plaza and the Whistler Sliding Centre. Vancouver had also previously bid for the 1976 games, which were first awarded to Denver, then to Innsbruck and the 1980 games, which were awarded to Lake Placid.
target: The villages of Whistler and Garibaldi bid for the games in 1976 but failed to win.

source: The 2010 Winter Olympics marked the first time an Olympic hockey game was played on a rink sized according to NHL rules instead of international specifications.
target: Vancouver 2010 was the first winter Olympics that both men's and women's hockey were played on a narrower, NHL-sized ice rink, measuring 200 ft × 85 ft (61 m × 26 m), instead of the international size of 200 ft × 98.5 ft (61 m × 30 m).

source: 82 National Olympic Committees (NOC) entered teams in the 2010 Winter Olympics.
target: Fifteen winter sports events were in the 2010 Winter Olympics.

source: Cayman Islands, Colombia, Ghana, Montenegro, Pakistan, Peru and Serbia made their winter Olympic debuts.
target: Cayman Islands, Colombia, Ghana, Montenegro, Pakistan, Peru and Serbia were in their first winter Olympics.

source: Also Jamaica, Mexico and Morocco returned to the Games after missing the Turin Games.
target: Also Jamaica, Mexico and Morocco came back to the Games after missing the Turin Games.

source: Ciara: The Evolution (simply known as The Evolution) is the second studio album by American singer Ciara, released on December 5, 2006, by LaFace Records.
target: Ciara: The Evolution (simply known as The Evolution) is the second studio album by American recording artist Ciara, released on December 5, 2006, by LaFace Records.

source: "Ciara: The Evolution" received mixed to positive reviews from most music critics.
target: "Ciara: The Evolution" received mixed reviews from music critics.

source: In economics and consumer theory, a Giffen good is a product that people consume more of as the price rises and vice versa—violating the basic law of demand in microeconomics.
target: In economics, a Giffen good is one that people consume more of when its price increases.

source: Pokémon Red Version and Pokémon Blue Version are role-playing video games developed by Game Freak and published by Nintendo for the Game Boy.
target: Pokémon Red (ポケットモンスター 赤, Poketto Monsutā Aka, "Pocket Monsters Red") and Pokémon Blue (ポケットモンスター 青, Poketto Monsutā Ao, "Pocket Monsters Blue"), released in Japan as Pokémon Red and Pokémon Green (ポケットモンスター 緑, Poketto Monsutā Midori, "Pocket Monsters Green"), are two role-playing games. They were made by Game Freak and published by Nintendo, and are the first two video games in the Pokémon series.

source: They were first released in Japan in 1996 as Pocket Monsters Red and Pocket Monsters Green, with the special edition Pocket Monsters Blue being released in Japan later that same year.
target: They were first released for the Game Boy in Japan in 1996.

source: "Pokémon Yellow Version", a special edition version, was released in Japan in 1998 and in other markets in 1999 and 2000.
target: "Pokémon Yellow", a special version, was released one year later in each region.

source: Remakes of "Pokémon Red" and "Green" for the Game Boy Advance, "Pokémon FireRed" and "LeafGreen", were released in 2004.
target: "Pokémon Red" and "Blue" have later been remade for the Game Boy Advance as "Pokémon FireRed" and "LeafGreen", released in 2004.

source: Both titles are independent of each other but feature the same plot, and while they can be played separately, it is necessary for players to trade among both games in order to obtain all of the first 150 Pokémon.
target: Both games have almost the same plot, but the player must trade among the two in order to complete the games' Pokédex.

source: As well as trading with each other and "Pokémon Yellow", "Pokémon Red" and "Blue" can trade Pokémon with the second generation of Pokémon games: "Pokémon Gold", "Silver", and "Crystal".
target: These three games ("Pokémon Red", "Blue", and "Yellow") and "Pokémon Stadium" make up the first generation of "Pokémon" video game series.

source: "Red" and "Blue" are incompatible with the "Pokémon" games of the later "Advanced Generation" for the Game Boy Advance or GameCube.
target: "Pokémon Red" and "Blue" are turn-based role-playing games.

source: "Pokémon Red" and "Blue" set the precedent for what has become a blockbuster, multibillion-dollar franchise.
target: "Pokémon Red" and "Blue" got good reviews, and their releases started the beginning of what would become a multibillion-dollar company, both selling millions of copies around the world.

source: Franchesse is a commune in the Allier department in central France.
target: Franchesse is a French commune. It is in the Allier department in the center of France.

source: The Falkland Islands ( ; , ] ) is an archipelago in the South Atlantic Ocean on the Patagonian Shelf. The islands are located in the South Atlantic Ocean, on the Patagonian Shelf, about 300 mi east of Patagonia in southern Argentina.
target: The Falkland Islands are a group of islands in the South Atlantic Ocean, off the coast of South America. The Falkland Islands are about 300 miles (480 km) east of Argentina.

source: Its sovereignty status is part of an ongoing dispute between Argentina and the United Kingdom.
target: Argentina disputes this, and claims their sovereignty.

source: The population (3,398 inhabitants in 2016) primarily consists of native-born Falkland Islanders, the majority of British descent.
target: As of the census of 2016, 3,398 people live on them.

source: The predominant (and official) language is English.
target: The people of the islands are British and speak English.

source: Under the British Nationality (Falkland Islands) Act 1983, Falkland Islanders are British citizens.
target: In 1983 the Falkland Islanders were granted British citizenship.

source: Major economic activities include fishing, tourism and sheep farming, with an emphasis on high-quality wool exports.
target: The main income for the people is from fishing and sheep farming.

source: The Falklands remained uninhabited until the 1764 establishment of Port Louis on East Falkland by French captain Louis Antoine de Bougainville, and the 1766 foundation of Port Egmont on Saunders Island by British captain John MacBride.
target: They were not inhabited until 1754, when a French captain landed and founded Port Louie.

source: Problems began when Spain discovered and captured Port Egmont in 1770.
target: Spain discovered and captured Port Egmont in 1770.

source: War was narrowly avoided by its restitution to Britain in 1771.
target: War was avoided by Spain giving it back to Britain in 1771.

source: In 1840, the Falklands became a Crown colony, and Scottish settlers subsequently established an official pastoral community.
target: In 1840 the Falkland Islands became a Crown Colony of the British nation.

source: In 1881, the Falkland Islands became financially independent of Britain.
target: The Falklands became a British Dependent Territory in 1981.

source: The Falklands governed these territories as the Falkland Islands Dependencies starting in 1908, and retained them until their dissolution in 1985.
target: This replaced the 1985 version.

source: The Falkland Islands are a self-governing British Overseas Territory.
target: In 2002 the Falklands became a British Overseas Territory with the British Overseas Territories Act 2002.

source: As a territory of the United Kingdom, the Falklands are part of the overseas countries and territories of the European Union.
target: They are an overseas territory of the United Kingdom.

source: The United Kingdom and Argentina both claim the Falkland Islands.
target: Argentina and the UK had a short war in 1982 because Argentina claims to own the islands.

source: The archipelago consists of two main islands, West Falkland and East Falkland, and about 776 smaller islands.
target: There are many islands in the group but the two biggest are East Falkland and West Falkland.

source: Lake County is one of the 64 counties in the U.S. state of Colorado.
target: Lake County is a county in the state of Colorado in the United States.

source: As of the 2010 census, the population was 7,310.
target: As of the 2010 census, 7,310 people lived there.

source: The county seat and the only municipality in the county is Leadville.
target: The county seat is Leadville.

source: The Yakovlev Yak-38 ( ; NATO reporting name: "Forger") was the Soviet Naval Aviation's only operational VTOL strike fighter aircraft in addition to being its first operational carrier-based fixed-wing aircraft.
target: The Yakovlev Yak-38 is a Soviet military single-turbojet aircraft.

source: If one of the takeoff engines failed, once the aircraft rolled past 60 degrees the pilot was automatically ejected from the aircraft.
target: It was designed and built as a fighter aircraft.

source: Sven Plex Petersson (7 August 1926 in Lit, Sweden – 25 June 2011 in Lidingö, Sweden) was a Swedish sports journalist, active for Sveriges Radio and Sveriges Television. He was employed by Sveriges Radio in 1957.
target: Sven Plex Petersson, born 7 August 1926 in Lit, Sweden, dead 25 June 2011 in Lidingö, Sweden was a Swedish sports journalist. He was active for Sveriges Radio and Sveriges Television. He was employed by Sveriges Radio in 1957.

source: Takehaya-Susano'o-no-Mikoto (建速須佐之男命 ) or Susano'o-no-mikoto (須佐之男命) in the Kojiki, or in the Nihon Shoki: Susanoo (Japanese: 素戔男尊、素戔嗚尊等、須佐乃袁尊 , also romanized as Susano-o, Susa-no-O, Susano'o, and Susanowo) , also called in the "Izumo-no-Kunifudoki" (出雲国風土記, lit: "The Chronicle of the Landscape Description of Izumo"): Kamususano'o (神須佐能袁命, 須佐能乎命 Susano'o) and Kumano Ketsumiko no Kami (熊野家都御子神) at Kumano shrine, is the Shinto god of the sea and storms.
target: Susanoo, (Japanese: 須佐之男命, "Susa-no-O-no-Mikoto"; also romanized as "Susano'o", "Susa-no-O", and "Susanowo") in Shinto is the Kami of the sea and storms.

source: In Japanese mythology, Susanoo, the powerful storm god, is the brother of Amaterasu, the goddess of the Sun, and of Tsukuyomi, the god of the Moon.
target: Susano'o is the brother of Amaterasu, the goddess of the sun, and of Tsukuyomi, the god of the moon.

source: All three were born from Izanagi, when he washed his face clean of the pollutants of Yomi, the underworld.
target: All three were created from Izanagi, when he washed his face to clean the dirtiness of Yomi, the underworld.

source: Amaterasu was born when Izanagi washed out his left eye, Tsukuyomi was born from the washing of the right eye, and Susanoo from the washing of the nose.
target: Amaterasu was born when Izanagi washed out his left eye, Tsukuyomi was born from the washing of the right eye, and Susano'o from the washing of the nose.

source: They tell of a long-standing rivalry between Susanoo and his sister.
target: The tales tell of great rivalry between Susano'o and his sister.

source: When he was to leave Heaven by orders of Izanagi, he went to bid his sister goodbye.
target: When he was to leave Heaven forever because Izanagi ordered him to, he went to say goodbye to his sister.

source: Amaterasu was suspicious, but when Susanoo proposed a challenge to prove his sincerity, she accepted.
target: Amaterasu, suspicious, proposed him a challenge: each of them was to turn an object of the other's into people.

source: Amaterasu birthed three women from Susanoo's Totsuka-no-Tsurugi while he birthed five men from her necklace.
target: Amaterasu created three women from Susano'o's sword while he created five men from her necklace.

source: In a fit of rage, he destroyed his sister's rice fields, hurled a flayed pony at her loom, and killed one of her attendants.
target: Susano'o destroyed her rice fields, threw a dead pony into her loom, and killed one of her assistants in anger.

source: Amaterasu, who was in fury and grief, hid inside the Ama-no-Iwato ("heavenly rock cave"), thus effectively hiding the sun for a long period of time.
target: For this, Amaterasu, sad, angry and scared, went to hide inside Ama-no-Iwato, the ""heavenly rock cave"", so the Sun was hidden and the world became dark for along time.

source: Though she was persuaded to leave the cave (with the help of a ceremony and a unique style of dancing), Susano-o was punished by being banished from Heaven.
target: Amaterasu later was made to come out of the cave, but Susano'o was punished by being banished from Heaven.

source: He descended to the province of Izumo, where he met an elderly couple who told him that seven of their eight daughters had been devoured by the eight-headed dragon Yamata no Orochi and it was nearing time for their eighth, Kushinada-hime (櫛名田比売 ) .
target: He came down to the province of Izumo, where he met an old couple.

source: This sacred sword, mirror and jewel collectively became the three Imperial Regalia of Japan.
target: The sword was given to Amaterasu as a reconciliation gift and was later given to her descendant Ninigi (the great-grandfather of Emperor Jimmu), with the "Yata-no-Kagami" (a mirror) and "magatama" (sacred jewels) as proof of his divine right to rule on Earth (the three Imperial Regalia of Japan).

source: Christopher James Paolini (born November 17, 1983 in Los Angeles, California) is an American author.
target: Christopher Paolini (born November 17, 1983 in Southern California) is an American writer.

source: He is the author of "The Inheritance Cycle", which consists of the books "Eragon", "Eldest", "Brisingr", and "Inheritance".
target: He is best known as the writer of the Inheritance cycle, which has the books "Eragon", "Eldest", "Brisingr", and the fourth book.

source: He lives in Paradise Valley, Montana, where he wrote his first book.
target: He lives in Paradise Valley, Montana.

source: "Eldest", the sequel to "Eragon", was released August 23, 2005. The third book in the cycle, "Brisingr", was released on September 20, 2008.
target: His second book, "Eldest", was released in 2005. His third book, "Brisingr", was released in 2008.

source: Although "The Inheritance Cycle" was originally planned as a trilogy, a fourth book, "Inheritance", was released on November 8, 2011 in the US, Australia, New Zealand, the EU, and India, and was subsequently translated and published in fifty-three countries.
target: The final book of the Inheritance Cycle, "Inheritance", was released on 8 November, 2011.

source: Mladé Bříště is a village in the Pelhřimov District, Vysočina Region of the Czech Republic.
target: Mladé Bříště is a village in the Pelhřimov District, Vysočina Region of the Czech Republic.

source: About 245 people live there and it has 5.33 km2 (1317.072 acres) of land.
target: About 245 people live there. It covers 5.33 km2.

source: It was first documented in 1226.
target: It was first documented in 1226.

source: The President of the Slovak Republic is the head of state of Slovakia and the commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces.

source: The Canadian Armed Forces (CAF; , "FAC"), or Canadian Forces (CF) ( , "FC"), are the unified armed forces of Canada, as constituted by the "National Defence Act", which states: "The Canadian Forces are the armed forces of Her Majesty raised by Canada and consist of one Service called the Canadian Armed Forces."
target: The Canadian Forces (CF) (French: Forces canadiennes; FC), is the army, air force, and navy of Canada, commanded by a single structure, unlike the United States. Under the National Defence Act, "The Canadian Forces are the armed forces of Her Majesty raised by Canada and consist of one Service called the Canadian Armed Forces."

source: The Commander-in-Chief of the Canadian Armed Forces is the reigning Canadian monarch, Queen Elizabeth II , who is represented by the Governor General of Canada.
target: The Commander in Chief of the Canadian Forces is the Head of State of Canada, Queen Elizabeth II, represented by the Governor General of Canada, David Lloyd Johnston.

source: During the Cold War, a principal focus of Canadian defence policy was contributing to the security of Europe in the face of the Soviet military threat.
target: During the Cold War, a major focus of the Canadian Forces was helping with the defence of Europe against the threat posed by the Soviet Union.

source: Toward that end, Canadian ground and air forces were based in Europe from the early 1950s until the early 1990s.
target: Some Canadian soldiers lived in Europe during that time.

source: Canadian defence policy today is based on the Canada First Defence Strategy, introduced in 2008.
target: Today, the Canadian Forces goals are based on the Canada First Defence Strategy, introduced by the conservative government of Stephen Harper.

source: The governor general appoints, on the advice of the prime minister, the Chief of the Defence Staff (CDS) as the highest ranking commissioned officer in the Armed Forces and who, as head of the Armed Forces Council, is in command of the Canadian Forces.
target: The Chief of the Defence Staff (or CDS), the senior professional member of the service, is General Thomas J. Lawson.

source: The Canadian Special Operations Forces Command (CANSOFCOM) is a formation capable of operating independently but primarily focused on generating special operations forces (SOF) elements to support CJOC.
target: The CANSOFCOM is responsible for providing special forces and asymmetric warfare capabilities to Canada.

source: The command includes Joint Task Force 2 (JTF2), the Canadian Joint Incident Response Unit (CJIRU) based at CFB Trenton, as well as the Canadian Special Operations Regiment (CSOR) and 427 Special Operations Aviation Squadron (SOAS) based at CFB Petawawa.
target: These units are the Joint Task Force 2, the Canadian Special Operations Regiment, the 427th Special Aviation Squadron and the Canadian Joint Incident Response Unit (CBRN).

source: This group is represented, though not commanded, at NDHQ by the Chief of Reserves and Employer Support, who is usually a major general or rear admiral, and is divided into four components that are each operationally and administratively responsible to its corresponding environmental command in the Regular Forcethe Naval Reserve (NAVRES), Land Force Reserve (LFR), and Air Reserve (AIRRES)in addition to one force that does not fall under an environmental command, the Health Services Reserve under the Canadian Forces Health Services Group.

source: Nut , also known by various other transcriptions, is the goddess of the sky, stars, cosmos, mothers, astronomy, and the universe in the ancient Egyptian religion.
target: In Egyptian mythology, Nut was the goddess of the sky. Egyptians called her "the mother of the sky".

source: Her name " ", itself also meaning "Sky", is usually transcribed as "Nut" but also sometimes appears in older sources as Nunut, Nent, and Nuit.
target: She had three other names: Nuit, Newet, and Nueth.

source: She had four or, in some sources, five children: Osiris, Set, Isis, Nephthys, and in some sources Horus.
target: The children were: Osiris was first, Horus was second, Set was third, Isis was fourth, and Nephthys was the fifth.

source: She was originally the goddess of the nighttime sky, but eventually became referred to as simply the sky goddess. In direct contrast to most other mythologies which usually develop a sky father associated with an Earth mother (or Mother Nature), she personified the sky and he the Earth.
target: She was the personification of the sky and the heavens. Nut was a very beautiful and kind goddess.

source: He decreed, "Nut shall not give birth any day of the year."
target: He told Nut that she could not have any children on any of the 360 days of the year.

source: She had five children: Osiris, later ruler of the gods and then god of the dead; Horus the Elder, god of war; Set, god of chaos and the desert; Isis, goddess of magic; and Nephthys, goddess of water.

source: Andalusia is located in the south of the Iberian peninsula, in southwestern Europe, immediately south of the autonomous communities of Extremadura and Castilla-La Mancha; west of the autonomous community of Murcia and the Mediterranean Sea; east of Portugal and the Atlantic Ocean; and north of the Mediterranean Sea and the Strait of Gibraltar.
target: Andalusia is in the south of the Iberian peninsula, just to the south of the autonomous communities of Extremadura and Castile-La Mancha; west of the autonomous community of Murcia and the Mediterranean Sea; east of Portugal and the Atlantic Ocean; and north of the Mediterranean Sea and the Strait of Gibraltar. The natural limits of Andalusia are: to the south, the Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea; to the north, the Sierra Morena, mountain range that separates Andalusia from the autonomous communities of Extremadura and Castilla-La Mancha; to the west is Portugal; and to the east is Murcia.

source: The small British overseas territory of Gibraltar shares a three-quarter-mile land border with the Andalusian province of Cádiz at the eastern end of the Strait of Gibraltar.
target: The small British Overseas Territory of Gibraltar shares a land border with the Andalusian province of Cádiz at the eastern end of the Strait of Gibraltar.

source: The name "Andalusia" is derived from the Arabic word "Al-Andalus" (الأندلس). In this period, the name "Al-Andalus" was applied to a much larger area than the present Andalusia, and in some periods it referred to nearly the entire Iberian peninsula. Its present form is derived from the Arabic name for Muslim Iberia, "Al-Andalus". However, the etymology of the name "Al-Andalus" is disputed, and the extent of Iberian territory encompassed by the name has changed over the centuries. This was a Castilianization of "Al-Andalusiya", the adjectival form of the Arabic language "al-Andalus", the name given by the Arabs to all of the Iberian territories under Muslim rule from 711 to 1492.
target: The name Andalusia is the modern version of the Arabic language "Al-Andalus" (الأندلس), name used by the Muslims for all of the territory of the Iberian Peninsula under their control. The Muslims used the name Al-Andalus for all of the territory of the Iberian Peninsula under their control.

source: The Andalusian emblem shows the figure of Hercules and two lions between the two pillars of Hercules that tradition situates on either side of the Strait of Gibraltar.
target: The Andalusian coat of arms shows the figure of Hercules and two lions between the two pillars of Hercules that tradition puts on both sides of the Strait of Gibraltar.

source: An inscription below, superimposed on an image of the flag of Andalusia reads "Andalucía por sí, para España y la Humanidad" ("Andalusia for herself, Spain and Humanity").
target: The words below read "Andalucía por sí, para España y la Humanidad" ("Andalusia by herself, for Spain and Humanity").

source: Over the two columns is a semicircular arch in the colors of the flag of Andalusia, with the Latin words "Dominator Hercules Fundator" (Lord Hercules is the Founder) superimposed.
target: Over the two columns is an arch in the colors of the flag of Andalusia, with the Latin words "Dominator Hercules Fundator".

source: The official flag of Andalusia consists of three equal horizontal stripes, colored green, white, and green respectively; the Andalusian coat of arms is superimposed on the central stripe.
target: The official flag of Andalusia has three equal horizontal stripes, colored green, white, and green respectively; the Andalusian coat of arms is on the central stripe.

source: Its design was overseen by Blas Infante and approved in the Assembly of Ronda (a 1918 gathering of Andalusian nationalists at Ronda).
target: It was approved in a meeting in 1918 of Andalusian nationalists at Ronda, a city in the province of Málaga.

source: The anthem of Andalusia was composed by José del Castillo Díaz (director of the Municipal Band of Seville, commonly known as Maestro Castillo) with lyrics by Blas Infante.
target: The anthem of Andalusia was composed by José del Castillo Díaz with lyrics by Blas Infante.

source: The music was inspired by "Santo Dios", a popular religious song sung at harvest time by peasants and day laborers in the provinces of Málaga, Seville, and Huelva.
target: The music was inspired by "Santo Dios", a religious folk song sung at harvest time by peasants.

source: The national holiday, the Día de Andalucía, is celebrated on 28 February, commemorating the 1980 autonomy referendum.
target: The national holiday, the "Día de Andalucía", is celebrated on 28 February.

source: Andalusia has a surface area of 87597 km2 , 17.3 percent of the territory of Spain.
target: It has a surface area of 87597 km2, 17.3 percent of the territory of Spain.

source: In general, it experiences a hot-summer Mediterranean climate, with dry summers influenced by the Azores High, but subject to occasional torrential rains and extremely hot temperatures.
target: In general, Andalusia has a Mediterranean climate, except in the Valley of Granada , with occasional heavy rains and extremely hot temperatures.

source: Andalusia is also home to the driest place in continental Europe, the Cabo de Gata, with only 117 mm of rain per year.
target: The place in Andalusia with the highest rainfall is in the Sierra de Grazalema (2138 mm per year) and the driest place is Cabo de Gata, the place with the least amount of rainfall in Europe with only 117 mm of rain per year.

source: In general, as one goes from west to east, away from the Atlantic, there is less precipitation.
target: Rainfall decreases from west to east.

source: The average temperature in Andalusia throughout the year is over 16 °C .
target: The average temperature in Andalusia throughout the year is over 16 °C.

source: Averages in the cities range from 15.1 °C in Baeza to 19.1 °C in Almería.
target: Averages in the cities range from 15.1 °C in Baeza to 18.5 °C in Málaga.

source: Much of the Guadalquivir valley and the Mediterranean coast has an average of about 18 °C .
target: Much of the Guadalquivir valley and the Mediterranean coast has an average of about 18 °C.

source: The coldest month is January when Granada at the foot of the Sierra Nevada experiences an average temperature of 6.4 °C .
target: The coldest month is January when Granada at the foot of the Sierra Nevada experiences an average temperature of 6.4 °C.

source: The hottest are July and August, with an average temperature of 28.5 °C for Andalusia as a whole.
target: The hottest are July and August, with an average temperature of 28.5 °C for Andalusia as a whole.

source: Córdoba is the hottest provincial capital, followed by Seville.
target: Córdoba is the hottest provincial capital, followed by Seville.

source: Ozone , or trioxygen, is an inorganic molecule with the chemical formula O3 .
target: Ozone, or trioxygen, is a chemical with the symbol O. Ozone is also called trioxygen.

source: Ozone is formed from dioxygen by the action of ultraviolet light (UV) and electrical discharges within the Earth's atmosphere. The highest levels of ozone in the atmosphere are in the stratosphere, in a region also known as the ozone layer between about 10 km and 50 km above the surface (or between about 6 and 31 miles). Ozone in the ozone layer filters out sunlight wavelengths from about 200 nm UV rays to 315 nm, with ozone peak absorption at about 250 nm. The Sun's UV sustains the ozone layer in the stratosphere of Earth. Production of ozone is one of the potential dangers of ultraviolet germicidal irradiation.
target: Ozone is formed from dioxygen by the action of ultraviolet light and also atmospheric electrical discharges. There is a portion of the stratosphere with a high concentration of ozone, called the ozone layer. The ozone layer filters out damaging ultraviolet radiation from the Sun, like a kind of sun screen. The Ozone layer is in the 10 to 50 kilometer range of the Earth's atmosphere.

source: It is present in very low concentrations throughout the latter, with its highest concentration high in the ozone layer of the stratosphere, which absorbs most of the Sun's ultraviolet (UV) radiation.
target: It is present in low concentrations throughout the Earth's atmosphere. The ozone layer also absorbs a lot of heat from the sun's rays.

source: Ozone is created naturally in the Earth's stratosphere, but is also created in the troposphere from human efforts.
target: Ozone is important to planet Earth.

source: Hundreds of studies suggest that ozone is harmful to people at levels currently found in urban areas .
target: However, ozone is toxic to animals and plants above concentrations of about 0.1 ppm.

source: Brampton ( or ) is a city in the Canadian province of Ontario. With a population of 593,638, Brampton is the third-largest city in the Greater Toronto Area, and the ninth-largest city in Canada.

source: Genocide is intentional action to destroy a people (usually defined as an ethnic, national, racial, or religious group) in whole or in part.
target: Genocide is the crime of killing many people who are all part of one ethnic or religious group, or some sort of similar group, and trying to destroy that group. Genocide is done usually by a group, such as a government, or military group, not by one person or a small number of people.

source: The hybrid word "genocide" is a combination of the Greek word "γένος" ("race, people") and the Latin suffix "-caedo" ("act of killing"). The term genocide was coined by Raphael Lemkin in his 1944 book "Axis Rule in Occupied Europe"; In 1944, Raphael Lemkin created the term "genocide" in his book "Axis Rule in Occupied Europe".
target: The word genocide was made up by Raphael Lemkin, a Polish Jew, in 1944, from the words "genos" (Greek for family, tribe or race) and "-cide" (from the Latin "occidere", to kill).

source: It contains an internationally recognized definition of genocide which has been incorporated into the national criminal legislation of many countries, and was also adopted by the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court, which established the International Criminal Court (ICC).
target: Today, any genocide is prohibited by the Genocide Convention and actor or inciter of genocide is judged by the International Criminal Court.

source: A tribal chief or chieftain is the leader of a tribal society or chiefdom.

source: Pop punk (also known as punk-pop or pop-punk) is a genre of rock music that combines influences of pop music with punk rock.
target: Pop-Punk or Punk-Pop, is a form of popular music that blends punk rock with pop music and rock music. Pop-punk music has a lighter, happier sound than most punk rock and hardcore punk music.

source: In the early–mid 1980s, punk rock bands such as the Descendents combined punk rock and hardcore punk with pop-influenced melodies and lyrical themes involving humor, girls, and teenage confusion.
target: Most punk rock and hardcore punk music sounds angry and harsh, and has lyrics (words) about protest and anger.

source: In the mid-1990s, pop punk broke into the mainstream with the mainstream success of Green Day, Rancid, and the Offspring. In the late 1990s, pop punk bands like Lit, Eve 6, and Blink-182 became mainstream and continued to be mainstream in the 2000s. Emo pop became successful during the late 1990s, with its popularity increasing in the early 2000s. Pop punk in the United States began to grow in popularity in the late 1980s especially in California due to bands like Dag Nasty and All, but the genre was not yet considered commercially viable by major US record labels.
target: In the 1990s, pop-punk became very popular in North America.

source: In visual arts, music, and other mediums, minimalism is an art movement that began in post–World War II Western art, most strongly with American visual arts in the 1960s and early 1970s.

source: Minimalism in visual art, generally referred to as "minimal art", "literalist art" and "ABC Art" emerged in New York in the early 1960s as new and older artists moved toward geometric abstraction; exploring via painting in the cases of Frank Stella, Kenneth Noland, Al Held, Ellsworth Kelly, Robert Ryman and others; and sculpture in the works of various artists including David Smith, Anthony Caro, Tony Smith, Sol LeWitt, Carl Andre, Dan Flavin, Donald Judd and others.
target: Minimalism in visual art, sometimes referred to as "literalist art" and "ABC Art" emerged in New York in the 1960s.

source: According to Lawson, minimalism was the result, even though the term "minimalism" was not generally embraced by the artists associated with it, and many practitioners of art designated minimalist by critics did not identify it as a movement as such.
target: The term "minimalism" was not generally embraced by the artists associated with it, and many practitioners of art called minimalist by critics did not identify it as a movement as such.

source: One of the first artists specifically associated with minimalism was the painter Frank Stella, four of whose early "black paintings" were included in the 1959 show, "," organized by Dorothy Miller at the Museum of Modern Art in New York.

source: There is nothing else in his painting."

source: These reductive works were in sharp contrast to the energy-filled and apparently highly subjective and emotionally charged paintings of Willem de Kooning or Franz Kline and, in terms of precedent among the previous generation of abstract expressionists, leaned more toward the less gestural, often somber, color field paintings of Barnett Newman and Mark Rothko.
target: These reductive works were in sharp contrast to the energy-filled and emotionally-charged expressionist paintings of Willem de Kooning or Franz Kline.

source: George Davis Snell (December 19, 1903 – June 6, 1996) was an American mouse geneticist and basic transplant immunologist.
target: George Davis Snell (December 19, 1903 – June 6, 1996) was an American mouse geneticist and basic transplant immunologist.

source: George Snell shared the 1980 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine with Baruj Benacerraf and Jean Dausset for their discoveries concerning "genetically determined structures on the cell surface that regulate immunological reactions".
target: He won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1980 with Baruj Benacerraf and Jean Dausset. They won it "for their discoveries concerning genetically determined structures on the cell surface that regulate immunological reactions".

source: Snell specifically "discovered the genetic factors that determine the possibilities of transplanting tissue from one individual to another.
target: Snell specifically "discovered the genetic factors that determine the possibilities of transplanting tissue from one individual to another.

source: It was Snell who introduced the concept of H antigens."
target: It was Snell who introduced the concept of H antigens."

source: George Snell was born in Bradford, Massachusetts, the youngest of three children.
target: He was the youngest of three children.

source: He received his Bachelor's degree from Dartmouth in 1926.
target: In 1926, Snell received a Bachelor's degree from Dartmouth College.

source: On the recommendation of John Gerould, his genetics professor at Dartmouth, Snell did graduate work at Harvard University with William E. Castle, the first American biologist to look for Mendelian inheritance in mammals.
target: After recommendation by John Gerould, his genetics professor at Dartmouth, Snell completed graduate work at Harvard University where he worked with William E. Castle.

source: Snell earned his PhD from Harvard in 1930. Upon receiving the Ph.D from Harvard, George Snell was employed as a teacher at Brown University, from 1930~1931.
target: In 1930, Snell earned his PhD from Harvard.

source: Not surprisingly, Snell studied the genetic effects of x-rays on mice with Muller.
target: He worked with H. J. Muller, a pioneer of radiation genetics (and later, a Nobel Prize winner).

source: From 1933~1934, Snell was a teacher at WUSTL.
target: Snell worked at WUSTL as a teacher from 1933 to 1934.

source: After brief stints as teachers, in 1935 Snell joined the staff of The Jackson Laboratory in Bar Harbor on beautiful Mount Desert Island by the coast of Maine and he remained there for the entire balance of his long career.
target: After he had some short stints as a teacher, Snell joined the Jackson Laboratory staff in Bar Harbor, Maine and spent the rest of his life there.

source: Snell received the Cancer Research Institute William B. Coley Award in 1978 for distinguished research in immunology.
target: Snell won the Wolf Prize in Medicine in 1978.

source: Snell died in Bar Harbor, Maine on June 6, 1996.
target: He died on June 6, 1996 in Bar Harbor, Maine.

source: S. Gopalan, pen-name Gopulu (18 June 1924 – 29 April 2015), was a Tamil illustrator and cartoonist, known for his work for the Tamil humour magazine "Ananda Vikatan".
target: S. Gopalan (1924 – 29 April 2015), better known as Gopulu, was an Indian illustrator and cartoonist. He was best known for his work for the Tamil humour magazine "Ananda Vikatan". He died on 29 April 2015, aged 91.

source: The Orinoco River (] ) is one of the longest rivers in South America at 2,140 km .
target: It is one of the longest rivers in South America, at 2,140 km.

source: Its drainage basin, sometimes known as the Orinoquia, covers , with 76.3 percent of it in Venezuela and the remainder in Colombia.
target: Its drainage basin, sometimes called the Orinoquia, covers 880,000 km2, with 76.3% of it in Venezuela and the rest in Colombia.

source: The Orinoco River and its tributaries are the major transportation system for eastern and interior Venezuela and the llanos of Colombia. Most of the important Venezuelan rivers are tributaries of the Orinoco River, the largest being the Caroní, which joins it at Puerto Ordaz, close to the Llovizna Falls.
target: The Orinoco and its tributaries are the main transport system for eastern and interior Venezuela and the llanos of Colombia. Most of the important rivers in Venezuela are tributaries of the Orinoco. The largest are the Caroní, which joins it at Puerto Ordaz.

source: The mouth of the Orinoco River at the Atlantic Ocean was documented by Columbus on 1August 1498, during his third voyage.
target: The mouth of the Orinoco was recorded by Christopher Columbus on 1 August 1498.

source: Its source at the Cerro Delgado–Chalbaud, in the Parima range, was not explored until 1951, 453 years later.
target: Its source, however, was first explored by non-native people in 1951, 453 years later.

source: The source, near the Venezuelan–Brazilian border, at 1047 m above sea level , was explored in 1951 by a joint Venezuelan–French team.
target: It was explored by a French and Venezuelan team. This is on the border between Venezuela and Brazil, at 1047 m high .

source: The Orinoco Delta, and tributaries in the eastern llanos such as the Apure and Meta, were explored in the 16th century by German expeditions under Ambrosius Ehinger and his successors.
target: The delta, and tributaries in the eastern llanos such as the Apure and Meta, were explored in the 16th century.

source: Alexander von Humboldt explored the basin in 1800, reporting on the pink river dolphins.
target: Alexander von Humboldt explored the basin in 1800.

source: At its mouth, the Orinoco River forms a wide delta that branches off into hundreds of rivers and waterways that flow through 41,000 km2 of swampy forests.
target: At its mouth, the Orinoco forms a wide delta that branches off into hundreds of rivers and waterways. They flow through 41,000 km2 of swampy forests.

source: In the rainy season, the Orinoco River can swell to a breadth of 22 km and a depth of 100 m .
target: In the rainy season, the Orinoco can swell to a breadth of 22 km and a depth of 100 m.

source: A peculiarity of the Orinoco river system is the Casiquiare canal, which starts as an arm of the Orinoco, and finds its way to the Rio Negro, a tributary of the Amazon, thus forming a 'natural canal' between Orinoco and Amazon.
target: This is a distributary of the Orinoco, flowing into the Rio Negro and then the Amazon. This connection forms a natural canal between Orinoco and Amazon.

source: The Orinoco crocodile is one of the rarest reptiles in the world.
target: It is the only habitat of the Orinoco crocodile. This is one of the rarest reptiles in the world, with fewer than 250 living in the wild.

source: The latter species, which is important in the aquarium industry, is also found in the Rio Negro, revealing the connection between this river and the Orinoco through the Casiquiare canal.
target: The river is actually connected to the Amazon River through the Casiquiare canal.

source: The river is navigable for most of its length, and dredging enables ocean ships to go as far as Ciudad Bolívar, at the confluence of the Caroní River, 435 km upstream.
target: Ocean ships can travel as far as Ciudad Bolívar, 435 km upstream.

source: River steamers carry cargo as far as Puerto Ayacucho and the Atures Rapids.
target: River steamers carry cargo as far as Puerto Ayacucho.

source: In 1926, a Venezuelan mining inspector found one of the richest iron ore deposits near the Orinoco delta, south of the city of San Felix on a mountain named "El Florero". The Orinoco River deposits also contain extensive tar sands in the Orinoco oil belt, which may be a source of future oil production.
target: There are also tar sands in the Orinoco Belt, which may be a source of future oil production. There is a rich iron ore deposit in the Orinoco delta. It was found in 1926, south of the town of San Felix on a mountain named "El Florero".

source: Full-scale mining of the ore deposits began after World War II, by a conglomerate of Venezuelan firms and US steel companies.
target: Mining there began after World War II.

source: At the start in the early 1950s, about 10,000 tons of ore-bearing soil was mined per day.
target: At the start in the early 1950s, about 10,000 tons of soil with ore in it was being mined each day.

source: The Wilson's bird-of-paradise ("Diphyllodes respublica") is a species of passerine bird of the family Paradisaeidae.
target: The Wilson's bird-of-paradise is a small bird of the Paradisaeidae family.

source: The male is a red and black bird-of-paradise, with a yellow mantle on its neck, light green mouth, rich blue feet and two curved violet tail feathers.
target: The male is a red and black bird-of-paradise with a yellow mantle on its neck, a light-green mouth, blue feet and two curved violet tail feathers.

source: The head is naked blue, with a black double cross pattern on it.
target: The head is naked blue with a black double cross pattern on it.

source: The female is a brownish bird with bare blue crown.
target: It is a brownish bird, though it does have a bare blue crown.

source: The subject (or proband) of the ahnentafel is listed as No. 1 , the subject's father as No. 2 and the mother as No. 3 , the paternal grandparents as No. 4 and No. 5 and the maternal grandparents as No. 6 and No. 7 , and so on, back through the generations.
target: In the table, a person is listed as number 1, the father is 2, the mother is 3.

source: In the German language, the term ""Ahnentafel"" may refer to a list of coats of arms and names of one's ancestors, even when it does not follow the numbered tabular representation given above.
target: An ancestor table (from German language "ahnentafel") is a family tree where people are shown in a numbered list instead of a tree.

source: Philip Stuart Brady (born 16 June 1939) is an Australian media personality, radio and television personality and voiceover born and raised in Melbourne.

target: In the 1970s, Brady hosted several television shows including "Moneymakers", "Casino Ten", "Password", "Get the Message", and "Everybody’s Talking".

source: Sumner Murray Redstone (born Sumner Murray Rothstein; May 27, 1923) is an American businessman and media magnate.
target: Sumner Murray Redstone (born Sumner Murray Rothstein; May 27, 1923) is an American businessman and media magnate.

target: He is the majority owner and chairman of the board of the National Amusements theater chain.

source: Through National Amusements, Redstone and his family are majority voting shareholders of CBS Corporation and Viacom (itself the parent company of Viacom Media Networks, BET Networks, and the film studio Paramount Pictures).
target: Redstone and his family are majority owners of CBS Corporation and Viacom (itself the parent company of Viacom Media Networks, BET Networks, and the movie studio Paramount Pictures).

source: According to "Forbes", as of September 2015, he was worth US$5 billion.
target: According to "Forbes", as of September 2015, he was worth US$5 billion.

target: Redstone was formerly the executive chairman of both CBS and Viacom. Redstone then became chairman emeritus.

source: In February 2016, at age 92, Redstone resigned both chairmanships following a court-ordered examination by a geriatric psychiatrist. In February 2016, at age 92, after a court-ordered examination by a geriatric psychiatrist whose findings were not publicly disclosed, Redstone relinquished the chairmanship of CBS to Moonves and the chairmanship of Viacom to Dauman.
target: In February 2016, at the age of 92, a week after a court-ordered examination by a geriatric psychiatrist, Redstone resigned both chairmanships, replaced by Leslie Moonves at CBS and Philippe Dauman at Viacom.

source: Attacks by Islamic extremists in Bangladesh refers to a period of turbulence in Bangladesh between 2013 and 2016 where attacks on a number of secularist and atheist writers, bloggers, and publishers in Bangladesh; foreigners; homosexuals; and religious minorities such as Hindus, Buddhists, Christians and Shias were seen.
target: In 2015, Islamic extremists killed four bloggers and a publisher in Bangladesh.

source: On 15 January 2013 Asif Mohiuddin, a self-described "militant atheist" blogger, was stabbed near his office in Motijheel, Dhaka. On the night of 15 February 2013, Ahmed Rajib Haider, an atheist blogger, was attacked while leaving his house in the Area Palashnagar of Mirpur neighborhood of Dhaka.
target: Ahmed Rajib Haider was hacked to death near his home in Dhaka in February 2013.

source: On 26 February 2015 bio-engineer Dr. Avijit Roy, a well-known Bangladeshi blogger, and his wife Bonya Ahmed were attacked in Dhaka by machete-wielding assailants.
target: Avijit Roy, a writer who started the blog Mukto-Mona, was hacked to death with machetes in Dhaka after a book fair.

source: His wife was slashed on her shoulders and the fingers of her left hand severed when she attempted to go to her husband's aid.
target: His wife, Rafida Bonya Ahmed, was hurt.

source: On 30 March 2015 another blogger, Washiqur Rahman, was killed in the Tejgaon neighborhood of Dhaka in an attack similar to that perpetrated on Avijit Roy.
target: Washiqur Rahman Babu was killed with knives at his house in Dhaka.

source: Ananta Bijoy Das, an atheist blogger who was on an extremist hit-list for his writing, was hacked to death by four masked men in Sylhet on 12 May 2015. Ananta wrote blogs for "Mukto-Mona".
target: Ananta Bijoy Das was a blogger with Avaijit Roy's Mukto-Mona.

source: On 23 April 2016 A. F. M. Rezaul Karim Siddique, a professor of English at the University of Rajshahi, was hacked to death by several unidentified assailants while waiting for a bus to the university campus in Rajshahi city.
target: Rezaul Karim Siddique, English professor was hacked to death in the city of Rajshahi, Bangladesh, after he organized a music school.

target: Nazimuddin Samad, a law student, was hacked and shot to death on a busy street in Dhaka.

source: Eric "X" (Swedish: Erik Knutsson; Old Norse: "Eiríkr Knútsson"; 1180 – 10 April 1216) was the King of Sweden between 1208 and 1216.
target: Eric X of Sweden (Erik Knutsson, c. 1180 - April 10, 1216) was the King of Sweden between 1208 and 1216.

source: However, they were overcome by King Sverker in the Battle of Älgarås in Tiveden, where all three of Eric's brothers were killed.
target: In 1205 he escaped from the Battle of Älgarås, where his three brothers were killed.

source: Eric survived and once again fled to Norway where he remained for three years.
target: He stayed for three years with family in Norway.

source: In 1208 he returned to Sweden under unknown circumstances but apparently with Birkebeiner assistance. In January 1208 Eric nevertheless defeated Sverker in the Battle of Lena and slew the Danish commander Ebbe Sunesen, whose troops suffered great losses.
target: He returned to Sweden in 1208 and defeated Sverker II of Sweden in the battle of Lena.

source: This did not have the desired effect, and in 1210 Sverker invaded Sweden in an attempt to reconquer the throne.
target: Sverker had attempted to regain the throne.

source: However, he was defeated in the Battle of Gestilren in July 1210.
target: Eric was elected king, but the coronation took place only in November 1210, after the Battle of Gestilren where he again defeated and killed Sverker II.

source: In the same year 1210 he married princess Richeza of Denmark, daughter of the late Valdemar I of Denmark, and sister of Valdemar Sejr.
target: He was married in 1210 to Rikissa of Denmark, the daughter of Valdemar I of Denmark and Sophia of Novgorod.

source: Not much is known about Eric's reign; written documents are few and do not give much insight in affairs during his time.
target: Very little is known about King Erik's reign, but it is said that the crops were good while he was king.

source: However, in 1216 Innocent III confirmed Eric in the rule, not only over his kingdom, but also over any pagan lands that he may conquer in the future.
target: In 1216, Pope Innocent III agreed that King Erik was King of Sweden, and also any other pagan lands he captured, probably Finland.

source: Eric died suddenly of natural causes on 10 April 1216 in Näs Castle on the island of Visingsö.
target: Erik died of a fever in 1216 at Nas Castle in Visingsö.

source: He was buried in the Varnhem Abbey Church.
target: He is buried in the Varnhems Church.

source: Hohenzollern-Hechingen was a small principality in southwestern Germany.
target: Hohenzollern-Hechingen was a county and principality in southwestern Germany, part of what is now Baden-Württemberg.

source: Its rulers belonged to the Swabian branch of the Hohenzollern dynasty.
target: Its rulers were members of a branch of the senior Swabian branch of the Hohenzollern family.

source: The County of Hohenzollern-Hechingen was created in 1576, upon the partition of the County of Hohenzollern, a fief of the Holy Roman Empire.
target: The County of Hohenzollern-Hechingen was created in 1576, when the County of Hohenzollern was divided. The county was ruled as a part of the Holy Roman Empire.

source: Unlike the Hohenzollerns of Brandenburg and Prussia, the Hohenzollerns of southwest Germany remained Roman Catholic.
target: Unlike the Hohenzollerns of Brandenburg and Prussia, the Hohenzollerns of southwest Germany remained Roman Catholic.

source: The County was raised to a principality in 1623.
target: The County was raised to a principality in 1623.

source: The principality joined the Confederation of the Rhine in 1806 and was a member state of the German Confederation between 1815 and 1850.
target: The principality joined the Confederation of the Rhine in 1806 and was a member state of the German Confederation between 1815 and 1850.

source: The democratic Revolution of 1848 was relatively successful in Hohenzollern, and on 16 May 1848, the Prince was forced to accept the establishment of a constitution.
target: The democratic Revolution of 1848 was relatively successful in Hohenzollern, and on 16 May 1848, the Prince was forced to accept the constitution limiting his power.

source: However, the conflict between monarch and democrats continued, and on 6 August 1849, Hohenzollern was occupied by Prussian forces.

target: Hägglund is the first female in Sweden who presented news on television. She was the news presenter of Aktuellt in 1958. Hägglund presented the national news show Aktuellt.

target: Her career started in 1955 when she started working for the Swedish radio. She was a secretary and program announcer.

source: Another novel, "Go Set a Watchman", was written in the mid-1950s and published in July 2015 as a "sequel", though it was later confirmed to be "To Kill a Mockingbird"' s first draft. On February 3, 2015, it was announced that HarperCollins would publish "Go Set a Watchman", which includes versions of many of the characters in "To Kill a Mockingbird".
target: However, in 2015, Lee announced "Go Set a Watchman", a sequel to "To Kill A Mockingbird".

source: Nelle Harper Lee was born on April 28, 1926, in Monroeville, Alabama where she grew up as the youngest of four children of Frances Cunningham (Finch) and Amasa Coleman Lee.
target: She was born in Monroeville, Alabama. In 1926, Harper Lee was born in the Monroeville, Alabama. She was the youngest child out of three children.

source: While enrolled at Monroe County High School, Lee developed an interest in English literature.
target: Harper Lee went to the Monroe County High School in Monroeville.

source: After graduating from high school in 1944, she attended the then all-female Huntingdon College in Montgomery for a year, then transferred to the University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa, where she studied law for several years and wrote for the university newspaper, but did not complete a degree.
target: She went to the all-female Huntingdon College in Montgomery following her sister who became a law expert.

source: During the next couple of years, she led Lee from one draft to the next until the book finally achieved its finished form and was retitled "To Kill a Mockingbird".
target: Two years later,it became "To Kill a Mockingbird."

source: Lee died in her sleep on the morning of February 19, 2016, aged 89.
target: Lee died on February 19, 2016, in a retirement facility in Monroeville, Alabama from complications of a stroke at the age of 89. Harper Lee died from a stroke at the age of 89, just seven months after the release of Go Set a Watchman, the controversial sequel To Kill a Mockingbird.

source: On February 20, her funeral was held at First United Methodist Church in Monroeville.

source: A planet is an astronomical body orbiting a star or stellar remnant that is massive enough to be rounded by its own gravity, is not massive enough to cause thermonuclear fusion, and has cleared its neighbouring region of planetesimals.
target: A planet is a large object such as Jupiter or Earth that orbits a star.

source: Planets are generally divided into two main types: large low-density giant planets, and smaller rocky terrestrials.
target: Planets are smaller than stars, and they do not produce light.

source: There are eight planets in the Solar System. The concept has expanded to include worlds not only in the Solar System, but in hundreds of other extrasolar systems.
target: There are eight planets in our Solar System. Until the 1990s, people only knew of those in the Solar System.

source: Several thousands of planets around other stars ("extrasolar planets" or "exoplanets") have been discovered in the Milky Way.
target: These newly found planets are orbiting other stars: they are "extrasolar" planets.

source: When the Romans studied Greek astronomy, they gave the planets their own gods' names: "Mercurius" (for Hermes), "Venus" (Aphrodite), "Mars" (Ares), "Iuppiter" (Zeus) and "Saturnus" (Cronus). Many of the Romance languages retain the old Roman word "terra" (or some variation of it) that was used with the meaning of "dry land" as opposed to "sea".
target: However, Earth is occasionally referred by the name of a Roman god: "Terra".

source: As of July 2008 the IAU has recognized five dwarf planets: Ceres in the asteroid belt, and Pluto, Haumea, Makemake, and Eris in the outer Solar System.
target: There are four more known dwarf planets in the Solar System, Ceres, Makemake, Eris and Haumea.

source: This effectively means that all planets are spherical or spheroidal.
target: Planets are shaped like a slightly squashed ball (called a spheroid).
