source: The London Array is a 175 turbine 630 MW Round 2 offshore wind farm located 20 km off the Kent coast in the outer Thames Estuary in the United Kingdom.
target: The London Array is an 175 turbine 630 MW offshore wind farm located 20 km off the Kent coast in the outer Thames Estuary in the United Kingdom.

source: Construction of phase 1 of the wind farm began in March 2011 and was completed by mid 2013, being formally inaugurated by the Prime Minister, David Cameron on 4 July 2013.
target: Construction of phase 1 of the wind farm began in March 2011 and was completed by mid 2013, being formally opened by the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, David Cameron, on 4 July 2013.

source: The second phase of the project was refused planning consent in 2014 due to concerns over the impact on sea birds.
target: The second phase of the project was refused planning consent in 2014 due to possible impacts on sea birds.

source: At the time of its construction it was the largest offshore wind farm in the world.
target: At the time of its construction it was the largest offshore wind farm in the world.

source: Malik Mir Sultan Khan (1905 – 25 April 1966) was the strongest chess master of his time from Asia.
target: Malik Mir Sultan Khan (1905 – 25 April 1966) was the strongest chess master of his time from Asia.

source: A servant from British India, he travelled with Colonel Nawab Sir Umar Hayat Khan ("Sir Umar"), his master, to Britain, where he took the chess world by storm.
target: He was a manservant from British India who travelled with his master, Colonel Nawab Sir Umar Hayat Khan, to Britain, where he took the chess world by storm.

source: In an international chess career of less than five years (1929–33), he won the British Championship three times in four tries (1929, 1932, 1933), and had tournament and match results that placed him among the top ten players in the world.
target: In an international chess career of less than five years (1929–33), he won the British Chess Championship three times in four tries (1929, 1932, 1933), and had tournament and match results that put him among the top ten players in the world.

source: Sir Umar then brought him back to his homeland, where he gave up chess and returned to his humble life.
target: Sir Umar then brought him back to his homeland, where he gave up chess and returned to his humble life.

source: David Hooper and Kenneth Whyld have called him "perhaps the greatest natural player of modern times".
target: He has been called "perhaps the greatest natural player of modern times".

source: By the time he was 21 he was considered the strongest player in Punjab.
target: By the time Sultan Khan was 21 he was the strongest player in the Punjab.

source: At that time, Sir Umar took him into his household with the idea of teaching him the European version of the game and introducing him to European master chess.
target: At that time, Sir Umar took him into his household with the idea of teaching him the European version of the game and introducing him to European master chess.

source: In 1928, he won the all-India championship, scoring eight wins, one draw, and no losses.
target: In 1928, he won the all-India championship, scoring eight wins, one draw, and no losses.

source: After the tournament, Winter and Yates trained with him to help prepare him for the British Chess Championship to be held that summer. Sultan Khan thrice played first board for England at Chess Olympiads.
target: After some training with British masters, Khan entered the British Chess Championship. Sultan Khan played three times on first board for England at Chess Olympiads.

source: To everyone's surprise, he won.
target: To everyone's surprise, he won.

source: Returning to Europe in May 1930, Sultan Khan began an international chess career that included wins over many of the world's leading players.
target: Next year, in May 1930, Sultan Khan began an international chess career in which he defeated many of the world's leading players.

source: His best results were second to Savielly Tartakower at Liège 1930; third at Hastings 1930–31 (+5−2=2) behind future World Champion Max Euwe and former World Champion José Raúl Capablanca; fourth at Hastings 1931–32; fourth at Bern 1932 (+10−3=2); and a tie for third with Isaac Kashdan at London 1932, behind World Champion Alexander Alekhine and Salo Flohr.
target: His best results were second to Savielly Tartakower at Liège 1930; third at the Hastings International Chess Congress 1930–31 behind future World Champion Max Euwe and former World Champion José Raúl Capablanca; fourth at Hastings 1931–32; fourth at Bern 1932; and a tie for third with at London 1932, behind World Champion Alexander Alekhine and Salo Flohr.

source: Sultan Khan again won the British Championship in 1932 and 1933.
target: Sultan Khan again won the British Championship in 1932 and 1933.

source: In matches he narrowly defeated Tartakower in 1931 (+4−3=5) and narrowly lost to Flohr in 1932 (+1−2=3).
target: In matches he defeated Tartakower in 1931 (four wins, five draws, and three losses) and narrowly lost to Flohr in 1932 (one win, three draws, and two losses).

source: He scored nine wins, four draws, and four losses (64.7%).
target: At the 3rd Chess Olympiad, Hamburg 1930, he scored nine wins, four draws, and four losses (64.7%).

source: At Prague 1931, he faced a much stronger field.
target: At the 4th Chess Olympiad, Prague 1931, he faced a much stronger field.

source: He had an outstanding result, scoring eight wins, seven draws, and two losses (67.6%).
target: He had an outstanding result, scoring eight wins, seven draws, and two losses (67.6%).

source: This included wins against Flohr and Akiba Rubinstein, and draws with Alekhine, Kashdan, Ernst Grünfeld, Gideon Ståhlberg, and Efim Bogolyubov.
target: This included wins against Flohr and Akiba Rubinstein, and draws with Alekhine, Kashdan, Ernst Grünfeld, Gideon Ståhlberg, and Efim Bogolyubov.

source: At Folkestone 1933, he had his worst result, an even score, winning four games, drawing six, and losing four.
target: At the 5th Chess Olympiad, Folkestone 1933, he had his worst result, an even score, winning four games, drawing six, and losing four.

source: Once again, his opponents included the world's best players, such as Alekhine, Flohr, Kashdan, Tartakower, Grünfeld, Ståhlberg, and Lajos Steiner.
target: Once again, his opponents included the world's best players, such as Alekhine, Flohr, Kashdan, Tartakower, Grünfeld, Ståhlberg, and Lajos Steiner.

source: In December 1933, Sir Umar took him back to India.
target: In December 1933, Sir Umar took him back to India.

source: In 1935, he won a match against V. K. Khadilkar, yielding just one draw in ten games.
target: In 1935, he won a match against V.K. Khadilkar, yielding just one draw in ten games.

source: The chess world never heard from him again.
target: After that, he was never heard of by the chess world again.

source: Although FIDE awarded titles to some long-retired players who had distinguished careers earlier in their lives, such as Rubinstein and Carlos Torre, it never awarded any title to Sultan Khan.
target: At the FIDE 1948 meeting, a number of former players were given retrospective titles, but not Khan.

target: Lake played Tracy Turnblad in the 1988 movie "Hairspray".

target: She recently hosted another talk show named "The Ricki Lake Show" which began in 2012.

source: Lake was born in Hastings-on-Hudson, New York, to a secular Jewish family. Her parents are Jill (a homemaker) and Barry Lake (a pharmacist), though Lake was largely brought up by her paternal grandmother, Sylvia Lake, until Sylvia's death in 1978.

target: They have two sons, Milo Sebastian Sussman born March 22, 1997 and Owen Tyler Sussman born June 18, 2001.

target: They separated in August 2003. Lake and Sussman divorced in 2005.

target: They were engaged in August 2011. Lake and Evans married on April 8, 2012.

source: The Meissner effect (or Meissner–Ochsenfeld effect) is the expulsion of a magnetic field from a superconductor during its transition to the superconducting state.
target: The Meissner effect is the expulsion of a magnetic field from a superconductor during its transition to the superconducting state.

source: The German physicists Walther Meissner and Robert Ochsenfeld discovered this phenomenon in 1933 by measuring the magnetic field distribution outside superconducting tin and lead samples.
target: The effect was discovered by Walter Meissner and Robert Ochsenfeld in 1933.

source: Pervis Ellison (born April 3, 1967) is an American former National Basketball Association (NBA) player.
target: Pervis Ellison (born April 3, 1967) is an American former professional basketball player.

target: Ellison earned the nickname "Never Nervous Pervis" due to his play at the University of Louisville, including leading the Cardinals to the 1986 national championship.

source: Nutritionism is a paradigm that assumes that it is the scientifically identified nutrients in foods that determine the value of individual food stuffs in the diet.
target: Nutritionism is the idea that only the nutritients found in different foods determines their value for the diet.

source: In other words, it is the idea that the nutritional value of a food is the sum of all its individual nutrients, vitamins, and other components.
target: The value of a diet can be calculated by adding up the values of all nutritients of the individual food items.

source: Pharmacokinetics (from Ancient Greek "pharmakon" "drug" and "kinetikos" "moving, putting in motion"; see chemical kinetics), sometimes abbreviated as PK, is a branch of pharmacology dedicated to determine the fate of substances administered to a living organism. Pharmacokinetics is the study of how an organism affects a drug, whereas pharmacodynamics (PD) is the study of how the drug affects the organism. Pharmacokinetics describes how the body affects a specific xenobiotic/chemical after administration through the mechanisms of absorption and distribution, as well as the metabolic changes of the substance in the body (e.g. by metabolic enzymes such as cytochrome P450 or glucuronosyltransferase enzymes), and the effects and routes of excretion of the metabolites of the drug. "Population pharmacokinetics" is the study of the sources and correlates of variability in drug concentrations among individuals who are the target patient population receiving clinically relevant doses of a drug of interest.
target: Pharmacokinetics is a branch of pharmacology which studies what the body does to a drug. Pharmacokinetics looks at how a substance enters, moves through and exits the body. It is closely related to another branch of pharmacology, pharmacodynamics, which describes how a drugs affects the body.

source: It attempts to analyze chemical metabolism and to discover the fate of a chemical from the moment that it is administered up to the point at which it is completely eliminated from the body.
target: Can be zero order or first order: This is an elimination process by which a drug or its metabolite is removed from the body.

source: These may affect the absorption rate.
target: The acidity of a pharmaceutical compound can also affect absorption.

source: Models have been developed to simplify conceptualization of the many processes that take place in the interaction between an organism and a chemical substance.
target: This model was developed in order to simplify perception of the many processes that take place once a drug enters an organism.

source: In pharmacokinetics, "steady state" refers to the situation where the overall intake of a drug is fairly in dynamic equilibrium with its elimination.
target: The state of constant maxima and minima is called "steady state".

source: It can therefore be seen that non-linearity can occur because of reasons that affect the entire pharmacokinetic sequence: absorption, distribution, metabolism and elimination.
target: The actual concentration of drug present within the plasma (bloodstream) following administration is dependent on absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion.

source: From this perspective the intravenous administration of a drug provides the greatest possible bioavailability, and this method is considered to yield a bioavailability of 1 (or 100%).
target: Some drugs undergo extensive first pass metabolism such that only about 10% of the administered dose enters the circulation: "10% bioavailability".

source: Bioavailability is therefore a mathematical factor for each individual drug that influences the administered dose.
target: The bioavailability (F) of the drug is the fraction of the drug being administered that reaches the blood circulation.

source: Tremaine Aldon Neverson (born November 28, 1984), known professionally as Trey Songz, is an American singer, songwriter, record producer and actor.

source: King's Highway 401, commonly referred to as Highway 401 and also known by its official name as the Macdonald–Cartier Freeway or colloquially as the four-oh-one, is a controlled-access 400-series highway in the Canadian province of Ontario.

source: By the end of 1952, three individual highways were numbered "Highway 401": the partially completed Toronto Bypass between Weston Road and Highway 11 (Yonge Street); Highway 2A between West Hill and Newcastle; and the Scenic Highway between Gananoque and Brockville, now known as the Thousand Islands Parkway.

source: Charles Bridge ( ] ) is a historic bridge that crosses the Vltava river in Prague, Czech Republic.
target: Charles Bridge is the oldest stone bridge in Europe.

source: Its construction started in 1357 under the auspices of King Charles IV, and finished in the beginning of the 15th century.
target: It had been constructed from 1357 to 1400.

source: This new bridge was originally called Stone Bridge ("Kamenný most") or Prague Bridge ("Pražský most") but has been "Charles Bridge" since 1870.
target: At first, it was called just "Stone Bridge" or "Praha Bridge." But it had the name of "Charles Bridge" since 1870.

source: As the only means of crossing the river Vltava (Moldau) until 1841, Charles Bridge was the most important connection between Prague Castle and the city's Old Town and adjacent areas.
target: Until 1841, this was the only bridge to connect old street of Prague.

source: This "solid-land" connection made Prague important as a trade route between Eastern and Western Europe.
target: It also played an very important role as the trade route between East and West zone of Prague.

source: The bridge is 621 m long and nearly 10 m wide, following the example of the Stone Bridge in Regensburg, it was built as a bow bridge with 16 arches shielded by ice guards.
target: Also, it has 16 arches.

source: Czech legend has it that construction began on Charles Bridge at 5:31am on 9 July 1357 with the first stone being laid by Charles IV himself.
target: There has been legend in this bridge.

source: Among the most notable sculptures, one can find the statuaries of St. Luthgard, the Holy Crucifix and Calvary, and John of Nepomuk.
target: At a railing of the bridge, there are thirty sculptures of saint who are famous in the Bible and History.

source: A computer virus is a type of malware that, when executed, replicates itself by modifying other computer programs and inserting its own code. Secondly, every computer virus must contain a routine to copy itself into the program which the search routine locates.
target: A computer virus is a program that is able to copy itself when it is run.

source: Motives for creating viruses can include seeking profit (e.g., with ransomware), desire to send a political message, personal amusement, to demonstrate that a vulnerability exists in software, for sabotage and denial of service, or simply because they wish to explore cybersecurity issues, artificial life and evolutionary algorithms.
target: Computer viruses are created for a cause, sometimes they are created to spread political messages and they are also created to hack some system files.

source: The term "virus" is also misused by extension to refer to other types of malware.
target: Very often, the term is also used for other kinds of malware, such as trojan horses and worms.

source: The majority of active malware threats are actually trojan horse programs or computer worms rather than computer viruses.
target: Most viruses are very dangerous kind of malware.

source: In his work Kraus postulated that computer programs can behave in a way similar to biological viruses.
target: Biological viruses also work that way, as they copy themselves as part of other organisms.

source: Some viruses, called polymorphic viruses, will employ a means of encryption inside an executable in which the virus is encrypted under certain events, such as the virus scanner being disabled for updates or the computer being rebooted. Some viruses employ polymorphic code in a way that constrains the mutation rate of the virus significantly.
target: Some viruses use something called polymorphic code to change their signature every time they move.

source: For this reason, many viruses attach themselves to executable files that may be part of legitimate programs (see code injection).
target: For this reason, computer viruses affect security.

source: Many Windows users are running the same set of applications, enabling viruses to rapidly spread among Microsoft Windows systems by targeting the same exploits on large numbers of hosts.
target: Computer viruses are spread through many ways.

source: Many users install antivirus software that can detect and eliminate known viruses when the computer attempts to download or run the executable file (which may be distributed as an email attachment, or on USB flash drives, for example). There are two common methods that an antivirus software application uses to detect viruses, as described in the antivirus software article.
target: Antivirus software can protect computers against known viruses.

source: Virus signatures are just strings of code that are used to identify individual viruses; for each virus, the antivirus designer tries to choose a unique signature string that will not be found in a legitimate program.
target: No matter how many signatures the company has, they will not be able to stop these types of viruses.

source: One may reduce the damage done by viruses by making regular backups of data (and the operating systems) on different media, that are either kept unconnected to the system (most of the time, as in a hard drive), read-only or not accessible for other reasons, such as using different file systems.
target: The best protection against viruses can be obtained by using a system that boots off a read-only medium, such as a compact disc (called CD), digital versatile disc (called DVD), or USB flash drive (called USB) that does not allow write access to hard disk (or other removable media).

source: As with many plates for countries within the European Union, a blue strip on the left shows a shortened country code in white text (D for = Germany) and the Flag of Europe (12 golden stars forming a circle on a blue background).
target: German licence plates show a "D" (for "Deutschland"="Germany") on the blue strip on the left, which shows the European Union's flag, 12 golden stars in a circle on blue ground.

source: The rest of the licence plate uses black print on a white background.
target: The present number plate format, used since 1994, uses black print on a white background and first provides information about the country where the car is registered within the European Union.

source: Just after the country code strip is a one, two or three letter abbreviation, which represents the city or region where the car was registered, such as B for Berlin.
target: After that, there are between one and three letters for the city or region where the car is registered, such as B for Berlin.

source: In some cases an urban district and the surrounding non-urban district share the same letter code.
target: These units usually coincide with the German districts, in few cases an urban district and the surrounding district share the same letter code. Usually if an urban district and a rural district share the code, the number of the following letters is different.

source: For example, the urban district of (SR) has one letter after the code (SR-A 123).
target: For example, the urban district (Straubing) SR has one letter after the code (SR - A 123).

source: The surrounding district has two letters (SR-AB 123) after the code.
target: The surrounding district Straubing-Bogen has two letters (SR - AB 123) after the code.

source: The largest German cities generally only have one-letter codes (B=Berlin, M=Munich, K=Cologne , F= , L= , S= ), most other districts in Germany have two or three letter codes.
target: The number of letters in the city/region code usually shows the size and location of the district: the largest German cities generally only have one letter codes (B=Berlin, M=München (Munich), K=Köln (Cologne), F=Frankfurt am Main), most other districts in Germany have two or three letter codes.

source: The reason for this scheme is however not to display size or location, but simply to have enough combinations available within the maximum length of eight characters per plate.
target: The reason for this scheme is however not to display size or location, but simply to have enough combinations available within the maximum length of eight characters per plate.

source: After the location name there are the round vehicle safety test and registration seal stickers (see below) placed above each other.
target: After the location name there are the emission test and vehicle safety test stickers (see below), followed by one or two letters and one to four numbers.

source: The total quantity of letters and numbers on the plate is never higher than eight.
target: The total quantity of letters and numbers on the plate is never higher than eight.

source: Identifiers consisting of one letter with low numbers are normally reserved for motorcycle use since there is less space for plates on these vehicles.
target: One letter with low numbers are normally reserved for motorcycle use since the plate space of these vehicles is smaller.

source: Various combinations that could be considered politically unacceptable – mainly due to implications relating to Nazi Germany – are disallowed or otherwise avoided.
target: Various combinations that could be considered politically unacceptable—mainly due to implications relating to Nazi Germany—are disallowed or otherwise avoided.

source: The district used the name of its main town, Pirna, in its code "PIR", to avoid the use of "SS", the name of the paramilitary organisation; similarly "SA" is also unused.
target: The district Sächsische Schweiz uses the name of its main town, Pirna, in its code "PIR", to avoid the use of "SS", the name of the nazi group; similarly "SA" is also unused.

source: In 2004 in Nuremberg, a car owner was refused a number plate beginning N-PD because of the connection to the political party the NPD.
target: In 2004 in Nuremberg, a car owner was refused a number plate beginning N-PD because of the connection to the political party, the NPD.

source: Banned combinations also include the Nazi abbreviations HJ ( , Hitler Youth), NS ( , National Socialism), SA , SS , KZ ( , concentration camp) and often SD .
target: Banned combinations include the Nazi abbreviations HJ ("Hitlerjugend", Hitler Youth), NS ("Nationalsozialismus", National Socialism), SA ("Sturmabteilung"), SS ("Schutzstaffel") and KZ ("Konzentrationslager", concentration camp).

source: Some registration offices have overlooked this rule by mistake, however, and there are a few cars registered carrying prohibited codes, such as "B-SS 12".
target: Some registration offices have overlooked this rule by mistake, however; there are a few cars registered carrying prohibited codes, such as "B-SS 12".

source: Some counties also allow these combinations if they are the initials of the owner (for example: might be able to get XX-NS 1234), but in this case, if the car is sold and re-registered in the same county by the new owner, the number can be changed (otherwise the number stays with the car until it registered in a different area).
target: Some counties also allow these combinations if they are the initials of the owner (e.g., Norbert Schmidt might be able to get XX-NS 1234), but in this case, if the car is sold and re-registered in the same county by the new owner, the number can be changed (otherwise the number stays with the car until it registered in a different area).

source: Trypanosoma is a genus of kinetoplastids (class Trypanosomatidae), a monophyletic group of unicellular parasitic flagellate protozoa.
target: Trypanosoma is a genus of parasitic protozoa. They are a monophyletic group of unicellular parasitic flagellate protozoa.

source: The majority of species are transmitted by blood-feeding invertebrates, but there are different mechanisms among the varying species.
target: Most are transmitted by a vector, usually by blood-feeding invertebrates. There are different mechanisms among the various species.

source: In an invertebrate host they are generally found in the intestine, but normally occupy the bloodstream or an intracellular environment in the mammalian host.
target: In an invertebrate host they are generally found in the intestine, but in their mammalian host they usually live in the bloodstream or inside cells.

source: Trypanosomes infect a variety of hosts and cause various diseases, including the fatal human diseases sleeping sickness, caused by "Trypanosoma brucei", Chagas disease, caused by "Trypanosoma cruzi."
target: Trypanosomes infect a variety of hosts and cause various diseases, including the fatal human diseases sleeping sickness, caused by "Trypanosoma brucei", and Chagas disease, caused by "Trypanosoma cruzi".

source: The mitochondrial genome of the "Trypanosoma", as well as of other kinetoplastids, known as the kinetoplast, is made up of a highly complex series of catenated circles and minicircles and requires a cohort of proteins for organisation during cell division.
target: The mitochondrial genome of the "Trypanosoma", and other kinetoplastids, is made of a highly complex series of circles and minicircles. It needs many proteins for organisation during cell division.

source: A mathematical model is a description of a system using mathematical concepts and language.
target: A mathematical model is a description of a system using mathematical concepts and language.

source: The process of developing a mathematical model is termed mathematical modeling.
target: The process of building a mathematical model is termed mathematical modeling.

source: Mathematical models are used in the natural sciences (such as physics, biology, earth science, chemistry) and engineering disciplines (such as computer science, electrical engineering), as well as in the social sciences (such as economics, psychology, sociology, political science).
target: Mathematical models are used in the natural sciences (such as physics, biology, earth science, meteorology) and engineering disciplines (e.g. computer science, artificial intelligence). They are also used in the social sciences (such as economics, psychology, sociology and political science).

source: Mathematical models can take many forms, including dynamical systems, statistical models, differential equations, or game theoretic models.
target: Mathematical models can take many forms.

source: These and other types of models can overlap, with a given model involving a variety of abstract structures.
target: The types of models include: These and other types of models can overlap, with a given model involving a variety of abstract structures.

source: In general, mathematical models may include logical models.
target: Mathematical models can include logical models.

source: In many cases, the quality of a scientific field depends on how well the mathematical models developed on the theoretical side agree with results of repeatable experiments.
target: In many cases, the quality of a scientific field depends on how well the mathematical models built on theory agree with results of repeatable experiments.

source: In engineering, physics models are often made by mathematical methods such as finite element analysis.
target: Physicists, engineers, statisticians, operations research analysts and economists use mathematical models a lot.

source: In legal terminology, a complaint is any formal legal document that sets out the facts and legal reasons (see: cause of action) that the filing party or parties (the plaintiff(s)) believes are sufficient to support a claim against the party or parties against whom the claim is brought (the defendant(s)) that entitles the plaintiff(s) to a remedy (either money damages or injunctive relief).

source: In some jurisdictions, specific types of criminal cases may also be commenced by the filing of a complaint, also sometimes called a criminal complaint or felony complaint.
target: In some jurisdictions, specific types of criminal cases may also be started by the filing of a complaint.

source: Most criminal cases are prosecuted in the name of the governmental authority that promulgates criminal statutes and enforces the police power of the state with the goal of seeking criminal sanctions, such as the State (also sometimes called the People) or Crown (in Commonwealth realms).
target: All criminal cases are prosecuted in the name of the governmental authority.

source: In the United States, the complaint is often associated with misdemeanor criminal charges presented by the prosecutor without the grand jury process.
target: In the United States, the complaint is often associated with misdemeanor charges presented by the prosecutor without the grand jury process.

source: In most U.S. jurisdictions, the charging instrument presented to and authorized by a grand jury is referred to as an indictment.
target: In most US jurisdictions, the document presented to and authorized by a grand jury is called an indictment.

source: More restrictively, literature refers to writing considered to be an art form or any single writing deemed to have artistic or intellectual value, often due to deploying language in ways that differ from ordinary usage.
target: Literature can also mean imaginative or creative writing, which is looked at for its artistic value.

target: The word "literature" comes from the Latin word "learning, writing, grammar".

source: Columbia is the capital and second largest city of the U.S. state of South Carolina, with a population estimate of 134,309 as of 2016.
target: Columbia is the capital and largest city of the U.S. state of South Carolina.

source: The city serves as the county seat of Richland County, and a portion of the city extends into neighboring Lexington County.
target: It is the county seat of Richland County, but a small portion of the city is in Lexington County.

source: Columbia is home to the University of South Carolina, the state's flagship university and the largest in the state, and is also the site of Fort Jackson, the largest United States Army installation for Basic Combat Training.
target: It is home to the University of South Carolina.

source: The fall line is the spot where a river becomes unnavigable when sailing upstream and where water flowing downstream can power a mill.
target: The fall line is the spot where boats cannot travel any farther upstream, and is also the spot farthest downstream where falling water can usefully power a mill.

source: The site was chosen as the new state capital in 1786, due to its central location in the state.
target: In 1786, the legislature decided to move the capital to the center of the state, and the site of Columbia was chosen for its location on the river just 13 miles (21 km) northwest of South Carolina's geographic center.

source: The State Legislature first met there in 1790.
target: The State Legislature first met there in 1790.

source: After remaining under the direct government of the legislature for the first two decades of its existence, Columbia was incorporated as a village in 1805 and then as a city in 1854.
target: After remaining under the direct government of the legislature for the first two decades of its existence, Columbia was incorporated as a village in 1805 and then as a city in 1854.

source: Columbia received a large stimulus to development when it was connected in a direct water route to Charleston by the Santee Canal.
target: Columbia received a large stimulus to development when it was connected in a direct water route to Charleston, by the Santee Canal.

source: This canal connected the Santee and Cooper rivers in a 22 mi section.
target: This canal connected the Santee and Cooper Rivers in a 22-mile (35 km) section.

source: It was first chartered in 1786 and completed in 1800, making it one of the earliest canals in the United States.
target: It was first chartered in 1786 and completed in 1800, making it one of the earliest canals in the United States.

source: With increased railroad traffic, it ceased operation around 1850.
target: With increased railroad traffic, it ceased operation around 1850.

source: As one of the first planned cities in the United States, Columbia began to grow rapidly.
target: Columbia was one of the first planned cities in the United States.

source: On February 17, 1865, in the last months of the Civil War, much of Columbia was destroyed by fire while being occupied by Union troops under the command of General William Tecumseh Sherman.
target: On February 17, 1865, during the Civil War, a fire destroyed much of Columbia was destroyed while being occupied by Union troops under the command of General William Tecumseh Sherman.

source: The first few years of the 20th century saw Columbia emerge as a regional textile manufacturing center.
target: The 20th century saw Columbia emerge as a regional textile manufacturing center.

source: Other major employers in the Columbia area include Computer Sciences Corporation, Fort Jackson, the U.S. Army's largest and most active initial entry training installation, Richland School District One, Humana/TriCare, and the United Parcel Service, which operates its Southeastern Regional Hub at the Columbia Metropolitan Airport.
target: Just east of the city is Fort Jackson, the U.S. Army's largest and most active initial entry training installation, Columbia is on the fall line from the Appalachian Mountains.

source: The city of Columbia has recently accomplished a number of urban redevelopment projects and has several more planned.
target: The city of Columbia has recently accomplished a number of redevelopment projects and has several more planned.

source: The historic Congaree Vista, a 1200 acre district running from the central business district toward the Congaree River, features a number of historic buildings that have been rehabilitated since its revitalization begun in the late 1980s.
target: The historic Congaree Vista, a 1200 acre district running from the central business district toward the Congaree river, features a number of historic buildings that have been rehabilitated.

source: Columbia is home to the main campus of the University of South Carolina, which was chartered in 1801 as South Carolina College and in 1906 as the University of South Carolina.
target: Columbia has the main campus of the University of South Carolina, which was chartered in 1801 as South Carolina College and in 1906 as the University of South Carolina.

source: The university has 350 degree programs and enrolls 31,964 students throughout fifteen degree-granting colleges and schools.
target: The university has 350 degree programs and enrolls more than 27,500 students throughout 15 degree-granting colleges and schools.

source: It is an urban university, located in downtown Columbia.
target: It is an urban university in downtown Columbia, just south of the Capitol.

source: The Comet, officially the Central Midlands Regional Transit Authority, is the agency responsible for operating mass transit in the greater Columbia area including Cayce, West Columbia, Forest Acres, Arcadia Lakes, Springdale, Lexington and the St. Andrews area.
target: The Central Midlands Regional Transit Authority (CMRTA), operates mass transit in the greater Columbia area including Cayce, West Columbia, Forest Acres, Arcadia Lakes, Springdale, and the St. Andrews area.

source: The authority was established in October 2002 after SCANA released ownership of public transportation back to the city of Columbia.
target: The authority was established in October 2002 after SCANA released ownership of public transportation back to the City of Columbia.

source: Since 2003, COMET has provided transportation for more than 2 million passengers, has expanded route services, and introduced 43 new ADA accessible buses offering a safer, more comfortable means of transportation.
target: Since 2003, CMRTA provides transportation for more than 2 million passengers, has expanded route services, and introduced 43 new ADA accessible buses offering a safer, more comfortable means of transportation.

source: CMRTA has also added 10 natural gas powered buses to the fleet.
target: CMRTA has also added 10 natural gas powered buses to the fleet.

source: The Central Midlands Council of Governments is in the process of investigating the potential for rail transit in the region.
target: The Central Midlands Council of Governments is in the process of investigating the potential for rail transit in the region.

source: Routes into downtown Columbia originating from Camden, Newberry, and Batesburg-Leesville are in consideration, as is a potential line between Columbia and Charlotte connecting the two mainlines of the future Southeastern High Speed Rail Corridor.
target: Routes into downtown Columbia originating from Camden, Newberry, and Batesburg-Leesville are in consideration, as is a potential line between Columbia and Charlotte connecting the two mainlines of the future Southeastern High Speed Rail Corridor.

source: Columbia's central location between the population centers of South Carolina has made it a transportation focal point with three interstate highways and one interstate spur.
target: Columbia's central location between the population centers of South Carolina has made it a transportation focal point with three interstate highways and one interstate spur.

target: The city and its surroundings are served by Columbia Metropolitan Airport (IATA:CAE; ICAO:KCAE).

target: The city is served daily by Amtrak and Greyhound Lines buses.

source: Adlai Ewing Stevenson II ( ; February 5, 1900 – July 14, 1965) was an American lawyer, politician, and diplomat.
target: Adlai Ewing Stevenson II (February 5, 1900 – July 14, 1965) was an American politician.

source: He was the 31st Governor of Illinois from 1949 to 1953, and received the Democratic Party's nomination for president in the 1952 and 1956 elections.
target: He was also the 31st Governor of Illinois from 1949-1953. Stevenson was Governor of Illinois from January 10, 1949-January 12, 1953.

source: In both the 1952 and 1956 elections, Stevenson was defeated in landslides by Republican Dwight D. Eisenhower.
target: He ran against Dwight D. Eisenhower in the 1952 and 1956 elections, but he lost. He also lost the 1952 and 1956 elections to Republican Dwight D. Eisenhower.

source: He sought the Democratic presidential nomination for a third time at the 1960 Democratic National Convention, but was defeated by Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts. After fending off a surprisingly strong challenge from Kennedy, Kefauver narrowly won the vice-presidential nomination on the second ballot.
target: He lost to Senator John F. Kennedy.

source: He served from 1961 until his death.
target: He became United States Ambassador to the United Nations from 1961 until his death in 1965.

source: He died on July 14, 1965, from heart failure (after a heart attack) in London, following a United Nations conference in Switzerland. On the afternoon of July 14, while walking in London with his aide and romantic partner Marietta Tree to Grosvenor Square, Stevenson suffered a massive heart attack, and died later that day of heart failure at St George's Hospital.
target: Stevenson suffered a heart attack on the afternoon and died later on July 14, 1965 in London of heart failure.

source: A maternal great-grandfather, Jesse W. Fell, had been a close friend and campaign manager for Abraham Lincoln in his 1858 US Senate race; Stevenson often referred to Fell as his favorite ancestor.
target: His maternal great-grandfather Jesse W. Fell was a close friend and campaign manager for Abraham Lincoln.

source: Stevenson's eldest son, Adlai E. Stevenson III, became a U.S. Senator from Illinois (1970–1981). They had three sons: Adlai Stevenson III, who would become a U.S. Senator; Borden Stevenson, and John Fell Stevenson.
target: His oldest son Adlai Stevenson III became a United States Senator from Illinois from 1970 until 1981. His son is former Illinois Senator Adlai Stevenson III.

source: Actor McLean Stevenson was a second cousin once removed.
target: Stevenson is a second cousin, once removed of actor McLean Stevenson.

source: Stevenson was raised in the city of Bloomington, Illinois; his family was a member of Bloomington's upper class and lived in one of the city's well-to-do neighborhoods.
target: He grew up in Bloomington, Illinois.

source: Stevenson left Bloomington High School after his junior year and attended University High School in Normal, Illinois, Bloomington's "twin city", just to the north.
target: He studied at Bloomington High School until his junior year. After that he went at University High School in Normal, Illinois.

source: In 1928, Stevenson married Ellen Borden, a well-to-do socialite.
target: He married Ellen Borden in 1928 and divorced in 1949.

source: He was elected a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1953.
target: In 1953, he was elected a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

source: Early in 1957, Stevenson resumed law practice, allying himself with Judge Simon H. Rifkind to create a law firm based in Washington, D.C. (Stevenson, Paul, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison), and a second firm in Chicago (Stevenson, Rifkind & Wirtz).
target: In 1957 he went back to law practice.

source: He was also employed part-time by the "Encyclopædia Britannica" as a legal consultant.
target: He was employed part-time by Encyclopædia Britannica.

source: Once Kennedy won the nomination, Stevenson, always an enormously popular public speaker, campaigned actively for him.
target: After Kennedy won the nomination, Stevenson campaigned for him.

source: Stevenson's refusal to publicly endorse Kennedy before the Democratic Convention was something that Kennedy "couldn't forgive", with JFK telling a Stevenson supporter after the election, "I'm not going to give him anything."
target: Stevenson refused to give the nomination address to John F. Kennedy.

source: During the Cuban Missile Crisis in October 1962, Stevenson gave a presentation at an emergency session of the Security Council.
target: Stevenson's most well-known moments happened during the Cuban Missile Crisis when he gave a presentation at an emergency session of the Security Council on October 25, 1962.

source: The funeral in Bloomington's Unitarian Church was attended by many national figures, including President Lyndon B. Johnson, Vice President Hubert Humphrey, and Chief Justice Earl Warren.
target: The funeral in Bloomington, Illinois Unitarian Church was attended by President Lyndon B. Johnson and Vice President Hubert Humphrey and Supreme Court Chief Justice Earl Warren.

source: The noble gases (historically also the inert gases; sometimes referred to as aerogens) make up a group of chemical elements with similar properties; under standard conditions, they are all odorless, colorless, monatomic gases with very low chemical reactivity.
target: The noble gases are a group of elements that are all gases.

source: For the first six periods of the periodic table, the noble gases are exactly the members of group 18.
target: These elements are all in group 18 of the periodic table.

source: A century later, in 1895, Lord Rayleigh discovered that samples of nitrogen from the air were of a different density than nitrogen resulting from chemical reactions. Rayleigh and Ramsay received the 1904 Nobel Prizes in Physics and in Chemistry, respectively, for their discovery of the noble gases; in the words of J. E. Cederblom, then president of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, "the discovery of an entirely new group of elements, of which no single representative had been known with any certainty, is something utterly unique in the history of chemistry, being intrinsically an advance in science of peculiar significance". The discovery of the noble gases aided in the development of a general understanding of atomic structure.
target: Noble gases were discovered by Lord Rayleigh and Sir William Ramsay. Rayleigh won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1904 for his work on noble gas. Ramsay won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1904 for his work with noble gas.

source: Learning from these experiments, Danish physicist Niels Bohr proposed in 1913 that the electrons in atoms are arranged in shells surrounding the nucleus, and that for all noble gases except helium the outermost shell always contains eight electrons.
target: This is because they have a full 8 electrons outer electron shell.

source: Noble gases can form endohedral fullerene compounds, in which the noble gas atom is trapped inside a fullerene molecule.
target: Noble gas compounds can be formed from noble gases.

source: The noble gases glow in distinctive colors when used inside gas-discharge lamps, such as "neon lights".
target: When the noble gases are used in cold cathode tubes to produce light, each of them has a different colour.
