source: Dieldrin is an organochloride originally produced in 1948 by J. Hyman & Co, Denver, as an insecticide.
target: Dieldrin is a chlorinated hydrocarbon originally produced in 1948 by J. Hyman & Co, Denver, as an insecticide.

source: Dieldrin is closely related to aldrin, which reacts further to form dieldrin.
target: Dieldrin is closely related to aldrin. Aldrin reacts further to form dieldrin.

source: Aldrin is not toxic to insects; it is oxidized in the insect to form dieldrin which is the active compound.
target: Aldrin is not toxic to insects; it is oxidized in the insect to form dieldrin which is the active compound.

source: Both dieldrin and aldrin are named after the Diels-Alder reaction which is used to form aldrin from a mixture of norbornadiene and hexachlorocyclopentadiene.
target: Both dieldrin and aldrin are named after the Diels-Alder reaction which is used to form aldrin from a mixture of norbornadiene and hexachlorocyclopentadiene.

source: Originally developed in the 1940s as an alternative to DDT, dieldrin proved to be a highly effective insecticide and was very widely used during the 1950s to early 1970s.
target: Dieldrin was developed as an alternative to DDT and has proved to be a highly effective insecticide. It was very widely used during the 1950s to early 1970s.

source: Endrin is a stereoisomer of dieldrin.
target: Endrin is a stereoisomer of dieldrin.

source: However, it is an extremely persistent organic pollutant; it does not easily break down.
target: However, it is an extremely persistent organic pollutant; it does not degrade easily.

source: Furthermore, it tends to biomagnify as it is passed along the food chain.
target: Furthermore it tends to biomagnify as it is passed along the food chain.

source: Long-term exposure has proven toxic to a very wide range of animals including humans, far greater than to the original insect targets.
target: Long-term exposure has proven toxic to a very wide range of animals including humans.

source: For this reason, it is now banned in most of the world.
target: For this reason it is now banned in most of the world.

source: It has been linked to health problems such as Parkinson's, breast cancer, and immune, reproductive, and nervous system damage.
target: It has been linked to health problems such as Parkinson's disease, breast cancer, and immune, reproductive, and nervous system damage.

source: It is also an endocrine disruptor, acting as an estrogen and antiandrogen, and can adversely affect testicular descent in the fetus if a pregnant woman is exposed to it.
target: It can also adversely affect testicular descent in the fetus if a pregnant woman is exposed to Dieldrin.

source: Dieldrin can be formed from the Diels-Alder reaction of hexachloro-1,3-cyclopentadiene with norbornadiene followed by epoxidation of the addition product
target: It can be formed from the synthesis of hexachloro-1,3-cyclopentadiene with norbornadiene in a Diels-Alder reaction, followed by epoxidation of the norbornene ring.

source: A volcanic eruption of Mount Ontake (御嶽山 , Ontake-san ) took place on September 27, 2014, killing 63 people.
target: A volcanic eruption of Mount Ontake (御嶽山, Ontake-san) took place on September 27, 2014, killing 63 people.

source: Mount Ontake is a volcano located on the Japanese island of Honshu around 100 kilometres (62 mi) northeast of Nagoya and around 200 km (120 mi) West of Tokyo.
target: Mount Ontake is a volcano located on the Japanese island of Honshu.

source: Walter G. "Skip" Campbell Jr. (November 12, 1948 – October 23, 2018) was an American Democratic politician who served as a member of the Florida Senate from 1996 to 2006.
target: Walter G. "Skip" Campbell, Jr. (November 12, 1948 – October 23, 2018) was an American Democratic politician. He was a member of the Florida Senate from 1996 to 2006.

source: Later, he served as the Mayor of Coral Springs, Florida, from 2014 until his death.
target: He was the Mayor of Coral Springs, Florida from 2014 until his death.

source: Campbell was born in Rockaway Beach, New York, in 1948 and moved to Florida in 1961.
target: Campbell was born in Queens, New York and moved to Ocala, Florida in 1961.

source: Campbell died at age 69 on October 23, 2018; he was recovering from a hip operation.
target: Campbell died on October 23, 2018 in Coral Springs from complications of hip surgery at the age of 69.

source: Rodney Agatupu Anoaʻ i (October 2, 1966 – October 23, 2000) was an American professional wrestler best known for his time with the World Wrestling Federation (WWF), where he wrestled under the ring name Yokozuna.
target: Rodney Agatupu Anoa'i (October 2, 1966 – October 23, 2000) was a professional wrestler. He is best known for wrestling for the World Wrestling Federation under the ring name Yokozuna.

source: In the WWF, Anoaʻ i was a two-time WWF World Heavyweight Champion and two-time WWF Tag Team Champion (with Owen Hart), as well as the winner of the 1993 Royal Rumble.
target: He was a two time WWF Champion and two-time Tag Team Champion and also won the 1993 Royal Rumble.

source: On October 23, 2000, Anoaʻ i died from pulmonary edema in his room at the Moat House Hotel in Liverpool while on an independent wrestling tour of Europe.
target: On October 23, 2000, Anoa'i died at the age of 34 from pulmonary edema in his room at the Moat House Hotel in Liverpool, England while touring for an independent wrestling show.

source: At the time, it was widely reported that he died of heart failure or a heart attack, but this was later found to be incorrect due to his lungs showing severe signs of blockage due to fluid.
target: At the time, it was reported that he died of heart failure or a heart attack but this was found to be incorrect because his lungs showed severe signs of blockage due to fluid.

source: On March 31, 2012, Yokozuna was inducted into the WWE Hall of Fame by his cousins, The Usos and Rikishi.
target: On March 31, 2012, he was inducted into the WWE Hall of Fame by Jimmy and Jey Uso and Rikishi.

source: Phil Rodgers (April 3, 1938 – June 26, 2018) was an American professional golfer.
target: Phil Rodgers (April 3, 1938 – June 26, 2018) was an American professional golfer.

source: Rodgers was born in San Diego, California.
target: He was born in San Diego, California.

source: He won the 1958 NCAA Division I Championship while playing at the University of Houston.
target: He won the 1958 NCAA Division I Championship while playing at the University of Houston.

source: Immediately after, he was placed in the first position on the first team of the 1958 All-American golf team, which included many well known professionals including future winners of the PGA Championship, Al Geiberger and Bobby Nichols and Masters Tournament winner, Tommy Aaron.
target: He was placed in the first position on the first team of the 1958 All-American golf team.

source: Despite some sensational wins, Rodgers seems better known for two losses.
target: Rodgers seems better known for two losses.

source: He lost to Bob Charles in a 36-hole playoff in the 1963 Open Championship.
target: Mainly when he lost to Bob Charles in a 36-hole playoff in the 1963 Open Championship.

source: Lesser known is that he lost the 1962 U.S. Open by two strokes despite going 6-over-par on two holes.
target: Lesser known is that he lost the 1962 U.S. Open by two strokes despite going 6-over-par on two holes.

source: Rodgers died in San Diego on June 26, 2018 from leukemia at the age of 80.
target: Rodgers died in San Diego on June 26, 2018 from leukemia at the age of 80.

source: Madalyn Murray O'Hair ("née" Mays; April 13, 1919 – September 29, 1995) was an American activist supporting atheism and separation of church and state.
target: Madalyn Murray O'Hair (April 13, 1919 – September 29, 1995) was an American atheist activist.

source: In 1963 she founded American Atheists and served as its president to 1986, after which her son Jon Garth Murray succeeded her.
target: She was the founder of the American Atheists and its president from 1963 to 1986.

source: She created the first issues of "American Atheist Magazine".
target: She created the first issues of "American Atheist Magazine".

source: In 1995, O'Hair, her second son Jon Garth Murray (known as "Garth"), and her granddaughter and adopted daughter Robin Murray O'Hair (daughter of William J. Murray (her son) and his high school girlfriend Susan), disappeared from Austin, Texas.
target: In 1995 she was kidnapped, murdered and dismembered along with her son Jon Murray and granddaughter Robin Murray O'Hair, by the former American Atheist office manager David Roland Waters.

source: Berry Gordy III (known professionally as Berry Gordy Jr., born November 28, 1929) is an American record executive, record producer, songwriter, film producer and television producer.
target: Berry Gordy Jr. (born November 28, 1929) is an American entrepreneur and producer.

source: He is best known as the founder of the Motown record label and its subsidiaries, which was the highest-earning African-American business for decades. The Tamla and Motown labels were then merged into a new company, Motown Record Corporation, incorporated on April 14, 1960.
target: He founded Motown Records.

source: Berry Gordy III (also known as Berry Gordy Jr.) was the seventh of eight children (Fuller, Esther, Anna, Loucye, George, Gwen, "Berry" and Robert), born on November 28, 1929 in Detroit, to the middle-class family of Berry Gordy II (also known as Berry Gordy Sr.), who had relocated to Detroit from Oconee in Washington County, Georgia, in 1922.
target: Gordy was born in Detroit.

source: Hurricane Agnes was the second tropical cyclone and first named storm of the 1972 Atlantic hurricane season.
target: Hurricane Agnes was a Category 1 hurricane in the 1972 Atlantic hurricane season.

source: In Florida, Agnes caused a significant tornado outbreak, with at least 26 confirmed twisters, two of which were spawned in Georgia.
target: As Agnes moved over the United States it caused a tornado outbreak.

source: Overall, Agnes caused 128 fatalities and nearly $3 billion in damage, though more recently, it is estimated that there were $2.1 billion in losses associated with the storm.
target: Agnes killed 130 people and caused $3 billion (USD) in damage.

source: Agnes was, at the time, the costliest hurricane to hit the United States in recorded history. Agnes was, at the time, the costliest hurricane in the history of the United States, though it has since been surpassed by numerous other storms.
target: At the time Hurricane Agnes was the costliest hurricane in the United States and the Atlantic Ocean.

source: Due to the significant effects, the name "Agnes" was retired in the spring of 1973. Because of extensive damage and severe death tolls, the name "Agnes" was retired following this storm, and will never again be used for another Atlantic hurricane.
target: Because of the high damage and high number of people killed, the name "Agnes" was retired.

source: Because the tropical cyclone naming lists were changed in 1979, there was no replacement name selected.
target: There was no name to be used instead of Agnes, because the list changed in 1979.

source: Gunpei Yokoi (Japanese: 横井 軍平 , Hepburn: Yokoi Gunpei , September 10, 1941 – October 4, 1997) , sometimes transliterated Gumpei Yokoi, was a Japanese video game designer.
target: Gunpei Yokoi (横井 軍平, Yokoi Gunpei, September 10, 1941–October 4, 1997), also romanized as Gumpei Yokoi, was a video game designer for Nintendo.

source: He was a long-time Nintendo employee, best known as creator of the Game & Watch handheld system, inventor of the "cross" shaped Control Pad, the original designer of the Game Boy, and producer of a few long-running and critically acclaimed video game franchises, such as "Metroid" and "Kid Icarus". He designed R.O.B. and the Game Boy, the latter of which became a worldwide success.
target: He created the Game Boy and the produced the "Metroid" series of video games.

source: Another of his creations, the Virtual Boy, was a commercial failure. Yokoi's death was confirmed two hours later.
target: Yokoi's last invention, the Virtual Boy, was not a success.

source: A multimeter or a multitester, also known as a VOM (volt-ohm-milliammeter), is an electronic measuring instrument that combines several measurement functions in one unit. A digital multimeter (DMM) is a device that provides multiple types of measurements within one device.
target: A multimeter or a multitester is an electronic measuring tool that is a combination of several tools in one unit.

source: A typical multimeter can measure voltage, current, and resistance.
target: Modern multimeters can be used to measure electrical quantities other than current, resistance and voltage. Most meters can measure volts, amps, and resistance. The multimeter can be used to measure the voltage of a battery.

source: Digital multimeters (DMM, DVOM) have a numeric display, and may also show a graphical bar representing the measured value.
target: Digital multimeters are sometimes called DMM too.

source: The Ottoman Empire followed in 1463 and lasted over 400 years.
target: After that era, the Ottoman Empire was on the rise.

source: The conflict eventually forced the Ottomans to cede administration of the country to Austria-Hungary through the Treaty of Berlin in 1878.
target: At the Berlin Congress in 1878, after the Russo-Turkish War, Austria-Hungary was given the rights to occupy and govern Bosnia and Herzegovina.

source: By the 6th century, Emperor Justinian had re-conquered the area and large parts of the former Western Empire for the Eastern Roman Empire with its capital in Constantinople.
target: The Romans occupied the area until their fall in the 6th century, but only to be conquered by the Byzantine Empire.

source: As the Ottoman Empire thrived and expanded into Central Europe, Bosnia was relieved of the pressures of being a frontier province and experienced a prolonged period of general welfare and prosperity.
target: As parts of the Ottoman borders shrank, Bosnia-occupied parts shrank apart.

source: Once the kingdom of Yugoslavia was conquered by Nazi forces in World War II, all of Bosnia was ceded to the Independent State of Croatia (NDH).
target: When Yugoslavia was invaded by Nazi Germany 1941, Bosnia and Herzegovina was made a part of Nazi-controlled Croatia.

source: The protests marked the largest outbreak of public anger over high unemployment and two decades of political inertia in the country since the end of the Bosnian War in 1995.
target: In 1995, the war ended.

source: Breakout is the second studio album by American recording artist Miley Cyrus, released on July 22, 2008 by Hollywood Records.
target: Breakout is the second studio album by singer Miley Cyrus. The album was released July 22, 2008.

source: "See You Again" (Rock Mafia Remix) was released August 11, 2008 as the second single from "Breakout"; it was only released in countries where the original version was not.
target: "See You Again (Rock Mafia Remix)" is the second single from the album, it was released on August 11, 2008, only in the United Kingdom as a promotional single.

source: Tecophilaeaceae is a family of flowering plants, placed in the order Asparagales of the monocots.
target: Tecophilaeaceae is a family of flowering plants in the order Asparagales.

source: It consists of nine genera with a total of 27 species.
target: It includes 8 genera and about 25 species.

source: Fossils at 20 million years ago include fragments attributed to "Victoriapithecus", the earliest Old World monkey.
target: Hominid fossils date from the Miocene.

source: (A few researchers go so far as to refer the chimpanzees and the gorillas to the genus "Homo" along with humans.)
target: However, if fossil hominids are included, then all the Australopithecines and the genus "Homo" are included.

source: In all great apes, the males are, on average, larger and stronger than the females, although the degree of sexual dimorphism varies greatly among species.
target: Males are larger than females.

source: Fox Kids originated as a programming block that aired on the Fox network from September 8, 1990 to September 7, 2002.
target: Fox Kids was a programming block on FOX in the 1990s, moving into the 2000s and stopping in 2001.

source: Howard Engel CM (April 2, 1931 – July 16, 2019) was a Canadian mystery author and CBC producer who resided in Toronto, Ontario.
target: Howard Engel CM (April 2, 1931 – July 17, 2019) was a Canadian mystery writer and CBC producer. Engel died of pneumonia on July 17, 2019 in Toronto at the age of 88.

source: He was famous for his Benny Cooperman detective series, set in the Niagara Region in and around the city of Grantham, Ontario; mirroring St. Catharines, Ontario, where he was born).
target: He was well known for his novel series of Benny Cooperman detective novels. He was born in St. Catharines, Ontario.

source: The Werribee River is a perennial river of the Port Phillip catchment that is located on the plain west of Melbourne, Victoria, Australia.
target: The Werribee River is a perennial river that flows across the volcanic plains west of Melbourne, Victoria, Australia.

source: In total the Werribee River completes a journey of approximately 110 km .
target: It begins in the hills near Ballan and flows for 110 kms before reaching Port Phillip Bay near the city of Werribee.

source: The river flows through the Werribee Gorge State Park before being utilised for irrigation of market gardens at Bacchus Marsh, then through Werribee where it is crossed by the Maltby By-pass.
target: Much of the area along the river is protected by parks, including the Werribee Gorge State Park. Water from the river is used to irrigate the market gardens of Bacchus Marsh and Werribee South.

source: It then flows through the Werribee Open Range Zoo in Werribee Park, and finally the small coastal settlement of Werribee South before entering Port Phillip.
target: The river also flows through the Werribee Open Range Zoo.

source: The Western Treatment Plant, a sewage treatment site, is located near the mouth of the river, and supplies irrigation needs to the zoo.
target: The Western Treatment Plant, the main sewerage treatment plant for Melbourne, is near the river mouth on the bay.

source: The Werribee River Trail winds beside the Werribee River from Davis Creek in Tarneit to the Princes Highway in Werribee.
target: The Werribee River Trail follows the river from Tarneit to Werribee. The Werribee River flows into the Melton Reservoir.

source: Before the arrival of white settlers, the Werribee River was the boundary of the Bunurong tribe whose six clans lived along the Victorian coast across the Mornington Peninsula, Western Port Bay to Wilsons Promontory.
target: Before the arrival of white settlers, the Werribee River was the boundary of the Bunurong tribe. Its six clans lived along the Victorian coast across the Mornington Peninsula, Western Port Bay to Wilsons Promontory.

source: In the late 1830s and 1840s, the Werribee River was the scene of conflicts between the Wautharong people and the European colonisers.
target: In the late 1830s and 1840s the Werribee River was the scene of fighting between the Wautharong people and the European settlers.

source: The squatter Charles Franks and a shepherd were speared to death near Mount Cottrell in July 1836.
target: The squatter Charles Franks and a shepherd were speared to death near Mount Cottrell in July 1836.

source: This resulted in a punitive party led by John Batman which came upon a large party of aborigines and indiscriminately shot and killed at least ten.
target: Because of this, John Batman led a group of men to punish the aborigines. They found a large group of aborigines and shot them, killing at least ten.

source: There are accounts of arsenic laced flour being given to local aborigines.
target: There are also reports of flour containing arsenic being given to local aborigines.

source: In 1851, a substantial timber bridge was built to cross the Werribee River to replace an earlier wooden bridge.
target: In 1851 a large timber bridge was built to cross the Werribee River to replace an earlier wooden bridge.

source: In 1852, this bridge was washed away when the Werribee river flooded.
target: In 1852 this bridge was washed away when the river flooded.

source: In August 2004, the Victorian Government pledged 300,000 towards restoring the Werribee River, removing willows choking the river around the township and replacing them with native plants in a habitat restoration project.
target: In August 2004 the Victorian Government promised $300,000 to fix the Werribee River.

source: The Hume and Hovell expedition camped by the river on 15 December 1824 and named it the "Arndell" after Hovell's father-in-law.
target: The explorers Hume and Hovell camped by the river on 15 December 1824.

source: John Helder Wedge 're-discovered' the river in 1835 and initially called it the "Peel", but then decided to call it the "Ex" or "Exe".
target: John Helder Wedge 're-discovered' the river in 1835 and at first called it the "Peel", but then changed it to the "Ex" or "Exe".

source: The name of the town of Exford, an early crossing place on the river, is derived from this name.
target: Exford, an early crossing place on the river, is based on this name.

source: One of the local Wathaurong-speaking Kulin tribesman that accompanied Wedge said the name for the stream was 'Weariby Yallock' ("yallock" meaning 'stream').
target: One of the local Wautharong speaking Kulin tribesman that accompanied Wedge said the name for the stream was 'Weariby Yallock' ('yallock' meaning 'stream').

source: The spelling changed to the present form of "Werribee", the original Aboriginal root word meaning "spine" or "backbone".
target: The spelling changed to the present form of "Werribee. T"he original aboriginal word meant "spine" or "backbone".

source: An extensive network of hard-surface bike and walking trails along the river allow visitors to view native flora and fauna that inhabit the river and its banks.
target: A network of bike and walking trails along the river showcase the many different kinds of plants and animals that live along the river.

source: There are many fishing spots along the river, and canoe- and boat-launching facilities are located at the Werribee South Boat Ramp and Riverbend Historical Park.
target: There are many things to do along the river. There are many fishing spots along the river. There are places to launch canoe and boats at the Werribee South Boat Ramp and Riverbend Historical Park.

source: Birdwatching is also a popular activity; however, care must be taken as there are known to be eastern brown snakes and other deadly fauna inhabiting the area.
target: Bird watching is also a popular activity. Care must be taken as there are Eastern Brown Snakes and other deadly fauna living near the river.

source: King of Arms is the senior rank of an officer of arms.
target: A King of arms is a government officer in countries like England, Scotland, and Wales. King of Arms is the highest rank of officer of arms. A King of Arms is also usually in charge of special ceremonies for a country.

source: Solihull ( , or ) is a large town in England with a population of 123,187 in the 2011 Census.
target: Solihull (, or ) is a large town in the West Midlands, England with a population of 123,187 in the 2011 Census.

source: Historically in Warwickshire, it is the largest town in, and administrative centre of, the larger Metropolitan Borough of Solihull, which itself has a population of 209,890.
target: It is the largest town in, and administrative centre of, the larger Metropolitan Borough of Solihull, which has a population of 209,890 people.

source: Solihull is situated 7.5 mi southeast of Birmingham, 18 mi northwest of Warwick and 110 mi northwest of London.
target: Solihull is located 7.5 mi southeast of Birmingham, 18 mi northwest of Warwick and 110 mi northwest of London.

source: Solihull is the most affluent town of the West Midlands, and one of the most affluent areas in the UK outside London.
target: Solihull is the most wealthy town of the West Midlands.

source: In November 2013, the uSwitch Quality of Life Index named Solihull the "best place to live" in the United Kingdom.
target: In November 2013, the uSwitch Quality of Life Index named Solihull the "best place to live" in the United Kingdom.

source: Residents of Solihull and those born in the town are referred to as "Silhillians".
target: Residents of Solihull and those born in the town are called "Silhillians".

source: The motto of Solihull is "Urbs in Rure" (Town in Country).
target: The motto of Solihull is "Urbs in Rure" (Town in Country).

source: Jennifer Ann McCarthy (born November 1, 1972) is an American actress, model, television host, author, screenwriter and anti-vaccine activist.
target: Jennifer Ann McCarthy, known as Jenny McCarthy, is an American model, actress, writer and activist.

source: She began her career in 1993 as a nude model for "Playboy" magazine and was later named their Playmate of the Year.
target: She started her career as a Playboy model in 1993.

source: She has promoted the disproven idea that vaccines cause autism, and she believes that chelation therapy helped cure her son of autism.
target: She said that chelation therapy helped cure her son of autism.

source: McCarthy was born on November 1, 1972 at Little Company of Mary Hospital located in the southwest Chicago suburb of Evergreen Park, Illinois.
target: She was born on November 1, 1972 in Evergreen Park, Illinois.

source: She lived in the West Elsdon neighborhood of Chicago.
target: She was raised in West Elsdon, Chicago.

source: The title of the show was changed to "The Jenny McCarthy Show" on July 12, 2016.
target: In 2013 McCarthy hosted a show called "The Jenny McCarthy Show" for one season.

source: McCarthy and Asher divorced in September 2005.
target: the couple divorced in 2005.

source: On April 16, 2014 McCarthy announced on the ABC talk show The View that she and Wahlberg were engaged, and they married on August 31, 2014.
target: She married Donnie Wahlberg in 2014.

source: In May 2007, McCarthy announced that her son Evan was diagnosed with autism in 2005.
target: In 2005, Evan was diagnosed with autism.

source: McCarthy's claims that vaccines cause autism are not supported by any medical evidence, and the original paper by Andrew Wakefield that formed the basis for the claims (and for whose book McCarthy wrote a foreword) was based on manipulated data and fraudulent research.
target: McCarthy has made controversial but unproven claims that vaccines lead to autism.

source: My Sister's Keeper is a 2004 novel written by Jodi Picoult.
target: My Sister's Keeper is a 2004 novel written by Jodi Picoult.

source: Anna Fitzgerald's older sister, Kate, suffers from acute promyelocytic leukemia, a blood and bone marrow cancer.
target: Anna Fitzgerald's older sister, Kate, suffers from acute promyelocytic leukemia, a cancer of the blood and bone marrow.

source: Anna was born as a savior sister specifically so she could save Kate's life.
target: Once Anna is born, her umbilical chord blood was used in treatments for Kate to save her life.

source: At first it is successful, but the cancer continues to relapse throughout Kate's life.
target: Although the treatment was initially successful, Kate relapsed (became sick again).

source: Anna is usually willing to donate whatever Kate needs, but when she turns 13, she is told that she will have to donate one of her kidneys due to Kate's kidney failure.
target: When Anna's parents learn about Kate's diagnosis, they decide to conceive Anna through artificial selection and in vitro fertilization because nobody in the family is a genetic match to donate organs to Kate.

source: Newhall is the southernmost and oldest community of Santa Clarita, California. It was the first permanent town in the Santa Clarita Valley.
target: Newhall is the southernmost district of Santa Clarita, California. It is the oldest district of Santa Clarita. It was the first permanent Anglo settlement in the valley.

source: Prior to the 1987 consolidation of Canyon Country, Saugus, Newhall, and other neighboring communities into the city of Santa Clarita, it was an unincorporated area.
target: Before 1987, Newhall was an independent but unincorporated town.

source: Named after businessman Henry Mayo Newhall, Newhall is home to the William S. Hart County Park, featuring tours of the famous silent movie maker's mansion.
target: It is named after businessman Henry Newhall. Newhall is home to the William S. Hart County Park. It has tours of the famous silent movie maker's mansion.

source: Over the years, Newhall has been the location for many movies, including "Suddenly" (1954) and Disney's "The World's Greatest Athlete" (1973).
target: Over the years, Newhall has been the location for many movies, including "Suddenly" (1954) and Disney's "The World's Greatest Athlete" (1973).

source: Sicco Leendert Mansholt (] ; 13 September 1908 – 29 June 1995) was a Dutch politician and diplomat of the defunct Social Democratic Workers' Party (SDAP) and later the Labour Party (PvdA) and farmer who served as the President of the European Commission from 1 March 1972 until 5 January 1973. He became President of the European Commission on 22 March 1972 (Mansholt Commission) and continued in that position until 5 January 1973.
target: Sicco Leendert Mansholt (]; 13 September 1908 – 29 June 1995) was a Dutch politician. He served as the 4th President of the European Commission from 1972 to 1973.

source: He resigned as Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food Supplies on 1 January 1958 and the First Hallstein Commission was installed on 7 January 1958.
target: He served as European Commissioner for Agriculture from 1958 to 1972, Minister of Agriculture, Fishing and Food Supply from 1945 to 1958, Minister of Economic Affairs in 1948 and Acting Mayor of Wieringermeer in 1945.

source: He was the youngest member of a cabinet, aged only 36.
target: He was a member of the Member of the House of Representatives on several occasions.

source: Central City (formerly known as Surrey Place Mall) is an award-winning mixed-use development that houses a shopping mall, a university campus and an office tower complex in Whalley / City Centre, Surrey, British Columbia, Canada, owned by Blackwood Partners Management Corporation.
target: Central City Shopping Centre (formerly Surrey Place Mall) is a Shopping mall and office tower in the Whalley neighborhood of Surrey, British Columbia.

source: The complex is located near two SkyTrain stations – Surrey Central and King George – and is the second-largest shopping centre in Surrey after Guildford Town Centre.
target: It is the second largest mall in Surrey, behind Guildford Town Centre.

source: In 2007, the rest of Central City mall was sold to Blackwood Partners Management Corporation.
target: In October 2007, the building was sold to Blackwood Partners Management Corporation of Toronto for $245.75 million.

source: Unlike other shopping centres in the region, and owing to its unique two-stage development, the main building of Simon Fraser University's Surrey campus is located within the mall and occupies a major portion (350000 sqft ) of the podium floors.
target: It is home to the Simon Fraser University - Surrey Campus.

source: Kanji (漢字 ) are the adopted logographic Chinese characters that are used in the Japanese writing system.
target: Kanji is one of the three forms of Japanese writing.

source: The Japanese term "kanji" for the Chinese characters literally means "Han characters".
target: The word “kanji” means “Han characters” (i.e. “Chinese characters”).

source: Thus the two other writing systems, hiragana and katakana, referred to collectively as "kana", are descended from kanji.
target: These systems are called hiragana and katakana (together they are called “kana”).

source: The "jōyō kanji" were introduced in 1981, replacing an older list of 1,850 characters known as the tōyō kanji (当用漢字 , general-use kanji) , introduced in 1946.
target: By the end of his school years a pupil should know about 1,850 kanji.

source: The "Dai Kan-Wa Jiten", which is considered to be comprehensive in Japan, contains about 50,000 characters.
target: There are many different Kanji, the exact number is not known but it is around 50,000.

source: Kanji readings are categorized as either "on'yomi" (literally "sound reading", from Chinese) or "kun'yomi" (literally "meaning reading", native Japanese), and most characters have at least two readings, at least one of each.
target: Most kanji characters can be pronounced at least two different ways according to whether the word is a native Japanese word (this is called the “kun” reading, or “kun-yomi”), or whether it came from Chinese (this called the “on” reading or “on-yomi”).

source: As with "on'yomi", there can be multiple "kun'yomi" for the same kanji, and some kanji have no "kun'yomi" at all.
target: For example, some native Japanese words with two or more kanji (usually proper nouns) use their kanji's kun-yomi, like 山口, which is pronounced "yama-guchi", even though the on-yomi for the kanji would be "san" and "kō" in that order.

source: This isolated kanji versus compound distinction gives words for similar concepts completely different pronunciations.
target: However, each kanji character can have several different pronunciations, according to which meaning (which “reading”) is intended.

source: In some cases the same kanji can appear in a given word with different readings.
target: There are even some words whose kanji can be used to only show a word's pronunciation and not its meaning.

source: Malay ( ; , ) is an Austronesian language spoken in Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore, as well as parts of Thailand.
target: The Malay language, or Bahasa Melayu, is a language spoken by ethnic Malays, an ethnic group that live in the Malay Peninsula and the Malay Archipelago in Southeast Asia, as well as the Austronesian people of the area.

source: In Malaysia, it is designated as either ("Malaysian language") or ("Malay language"). In Singapore and Brunei, it is called ("Malay language") and in Indonesia, an autonomous normative variety called ("Indonesian language") is designated the ("unifying language"/lingua franca).
target: In Malaysia, the language is registered as "Bahasa Malaysia", "Malaysian". In Singapore, Brunei and Thailand is referred to as "Bahasa Melayu", "Malay language". Malay is distinguished as a local language in Indonesia as opposed to the national language, Bahasa Indonesia.

source: Malay, like most Austronesian languages, is not a tonal language. Malay is a member of the Austronesian family of languages, which includes languages from Southeast Asia and the Pacific Ocean, with a smaller number in continental Asia.
target: The Malay language is part of the Austronesian family of languages.

source: Malay is now written using the Latin script ("Rumi"), although an Arabic script called "Arab Melayu" or "Jawi" also exists.
target: Malay is normally written with the Latin alphabet called Rumi. But there is also a modified Arabic alphabet that is called Jawi.

source: "Rumi" is official in Malaysia, Singapore, and Indonesia.
target: Rumi is official in Malaysia and Singapore, and the Indonesian language has a different official orthography that uses also the Latin script.

source: "Rumi" and "Jawi" are co-official in Brunei only.
target: Rumi and Jawi are both official in Brunei.

source: Efforts are currently being undertaken to preserve Jawi in rural areas of Malaysia, and students taking Malay language examinations in Malaysia have the option of answering questions using Jawi.
target: Efforts are currently being undertaken to preserve Jawi script and to revive its use amongst Malays in Malaysia, and students taking Malay language examination in Malaysia have the option of answering questions using Jawi script.

source: The Latin script, however, is the most commonly used in Brunei and Malaysia, both for official and informal purposes.
target: But the Latin alphabet is still the most commonly used script in Malaysia, both for official and informal purposes.

source: Historically, Malay has been written using various scripts.
target: Historically, Malay has been written in various types of script.

source: Before the introduction of Arabic script in the Malay region, Malay was written using the Pallava, Kawi and Rencong scripts; these are still in use today, such as the Cham alphabet used by the Chams of Vietnam and Cambodia.
target: Before the introduction of Arabic script in the Malay region, Malay was written using Pallava, Kawi and Rencong script and are still in use today by the Champa Malay in Vietnam and Cambodia.

source: Malay is spoken in Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, East Timor, Singapore, parts of Thailand and southern Philippines.
target: It is the national language of Malaysia (Malaysian), Brunei, Indonesia (Indonesian), an official language in Singapore, a working language in East Timor (Indonesian), and a recognized and significant minority in Thailand, Vietnam, Philippines and Cambodia.

source: Brunei, in addition to Standard Malay, uses a distinct vernacular dialect called Brunei Malay.
target: Bahasa Melayu is Brunei's national language but Bruneians also speak their own dialect of Malay, known as "Brunei Melayu" or "Bruneian Malay".

source: Most residents of the five southernmost provinces of Thailand — a region that, for the most part, used to be part of an ancient Malay kingdom called Pattani — speak a dialect of Malay called Yawi (not to be confused with Jawi), which is similar to Kelantanese Malay, but the language has no official status or recognition.
target: In southern Thailand, the Malays living in the country do speak Bahasa Melayu, but their also speak a distinct dialect of Malay, known as Yawi or "Bahasa Jawi".

source: The eastern varieties, classified either as dialects or creoles, are spoken in the easternmost part of the Indonesian archipelago and include: Manado Malay, Ambonese Malay, North Moluccan Malay, Papuan Malay.
target: There are innumerable dialects, creoles, versions and forms of Malay.

source: Daugavpils (] ; ] ; ] ; ; see other names) is a city in south-eastern Latvia, located on the banks of the Daugava River, from which the city gets its name.
target: Daugavpils (] ; ]; ]) is a city in southeastern Latvia. It is on the banks of the Daugava River, from which the city gets its name.

source: It is the second largest city in the country after the capital Riga, which is located some 230 km to its north-west.
target: It is the second largest city in the country after the capital Riga.

source: Richard Alvin Jensen (July 4, 1934 – November 19, 2014) was an American theologian, author, and the Carlson Professor of Homiletics Emeritus at the Lutheran School of Theology at Chicago.
target: Richard Alvin Jensen (July 4, 1934 – November 19, 2014) was an American theologian, author, and the Carlson Professor of Homiletics Emeritus at the Lutheran School of Theology at Chicago.

source: Jensen was born on July 4, 1934, in Fremont, Nebraska.
target: Jensen was born in Fremont, Nebraska.

source: On November 19, 2014, he died at the age of 80.
target: Jensen died in Lakeville, Minnesota, aged 80.

source: Umeå IK ] is a women's association football club based in the city of Umeå, Sweden.
target: Umeå IK is a women's association football club that is from Umeå, Sweden.

source: Established in 1917 as a general sports club, the women's football section began competing in 1985.
target: It was founded in 1917 It was started as a as a general sports club.

source: Umeå IK has won seven Swedish championships (2000, 2001, 2002, 2005, 2006, 2007 and 2008), four Swedish Cups (2001, 2002, 2003 and 2007) and the UEFA Women's Champions League twice, in 2003 and 2004.
target: The club won the Swedish national championship in 2000, 2001, 2002, 2005.,

source: The team colours are black and yellow.
target: The team's colours are black and yellow.

source: Fenella Fielding, OBE (17 November 1927 – 11 September 2018) was an English stage, film and television actress who rose to prominence in the 1950s and 1960s, and was often referred to as "England's first lady of the double entendre".
target: Fenella Fielding, OBE (17 November 1927 – 11 September 2018) was an English stage, movie and television actress. She was very popular in the 1950s and 1960s. She was known as "England's first lady of the double entendre".

source: She was known for her seductive image and distinctively husky voice.
target: She was known for her husky voice.

source: Fielding appeared in two "Carry On" films, "Carry On Regardless" (1961) and "Carry On Screaming!"
target: Fielding appeared in two "Carry On" movies, "Carry On Regardless" (1961) and "Carry On Screaming!"

source: Fielding also starred in the children's television series "Uncle Jack" from 1990-1993 as the notorious villainess, The Vixen.
target: Fielding also starred in the children's television series "Uncle Jack" from 1990-1993 as The Vixen.

source: In 1999, Fielding starred in Rik Mayall and Adrian Edmondson's film "Guest House Paradiso".
target: In 1999, Fielding starred in Rik Mayall and Adrian Edmondson's movie "Guest House Paradiso".

source: Fielding suffered a stroke on 25 August 2018 and died two weeks later at Charing Cross Hospital in Hammersmith, on 11 September 2018, aged 90.
target: In August 2018, Fielding suffered a severe stroke in London. She died a month later on 11 September 2018 at the age of 90.
